In fact the Emancipation Proclamation didn't even ban slavery outright, it just said that the states that had just declared secession from the U.S. weren't allowed to own slaves while providing exemptions to northern territories. Less than half of the states that attempted to secede even mentioned slavery at all in their grievances, which were largely a miles long list of tax slights and the mexican-american war that left those states feeling as though they were being used and abused by their northern neighbors, who then decided to use slavery as a wedge issue for ye olde optics cuckery. In fact, slavery was such a non issue that when the north was losing the war, you know before Sherman decided to start doing war crimes like doing things that rhyme with graping and pillaging and enslaving unarmed women and children in non-combat zones to demoralize the south, Lincoln offered to repeal the Emancipation Proclamation and motion to codify slavery into the Constitution as a right if the south would just rejoin the Union. Actually a funny little thing about that is that slaves couldn't be drafted, but freedmen could, so many of the slaves "rescued" from the south were immediately conscripted by force into the Union and sent to the front lines as cannon fodder. Secession Documents: When states seceded from the Union, they often issued declarations explaining their reasons. The Mississippi Declaration of Secession, for example, explicitly states: "Our position is thoroughly identified with the institution of slavery‚Äîthe greatest material interest of the world." Similarly, the Texas Declaration of Secession argues that the federal government had failed to protect the institution of slavery.  Confederate Constitution: The Confederate Constitution was very similar to the U.S. Constitution, with one key difference: it explicitly protected the institution of slavery and prohibited the Confederate government from ever interfering with it.  The Cornerstone Speech: In his "Cornerstone Speech," Confederate Vice President Alexander Stephens stated that the Confederacy was founded on the idea that "the negro is not equal to the white man; that slavery subordination to the superior race is his natural and normal condition."  The "States' Rights" Argument in Context: The "states' rights" argument was not a new one. Southern states had long used it to resist federal policies they believed threatened their way of life, especially those related to slavery. For example, they opposed federal tariffs and internal improvements (like roads and canals) because they feared that a strong federal government might eventually try to abolish slavery. However, the states' rights argument was selectively applied. When Northern states tried to exercise their "states' rights" by passing "personal liberty laws" that made it difficult for slave catchers to operate, Southern states demanded federal intervention and the passage of the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850. It was about slavery through and through.

I visited a civil war exhibit in alabama, they shared a bit of what was essentially the confederacies declaration of independence. Only part way down the page where it started to blur and fade out they emphasised that one of the biggest issues was the right to own slaves. I appreciate when folks recognize that there was more to it than just that, but pretending it wasnt one of the most defining issues if not the most defining issue the conflict orbited around is just wrong.   From the adoption of the constitution this was a controversial issue one the founding fathers thought could be solved peacefully with a slow phasing out of slavery over time, that timetable got changed and eventually removed in favor of an unsteady split in the country, and eventually was one of the main motivators for secession. They rightly feared that slavery would be outlawed, and though moderates in the north were trying to still ride the line for the sake of peace and find a compromise it was always only a matter of time until it came to a head.   The south wanting states to have more power and wanting to avoid federal abolishment of slavery tried to secede first with General Lee remarking that he was a Virginian first before he was an American. They flirted with other countries and even purchased equipment from the likes of Britain but in the end Abraham Lincoln recognized that the war could not just be about keeping the country together but had to address one of the biggest if not the biggest issues at the heart of the conflict, slavery and whether states had the right to continue the practice of their own choice or if the federal government could enforce the intent of the constitution onto them and abolish it. This discouraged other countries and the norths industrial base helped them solidify their naval edge. The remainder is history.

There's not much about the Confederacy worth supporting in the year 2025. The issues they fought for and their ideals were so far removed from our current day. They fought for the right to maintain the slave class, and they maintained a lot of hateful & harmful rhetoric.  But it doesn't really stop there. WHY did they want to maintain slavery? That's the question a lot of people choose either not to ask, or not to take seriously. Because if your answer is more or less "Because they were hateful, felt superior & chose to reflect that in their actions," then you are not correct. This country wasn't founded by Hollywood super villains. It was founded by ignorant people who themselves were products of a racist/classist system, & who themselves eventually became split by class. Poorer rural southerners attempted to maintain sponsorships with Britain that sustained them. To whoever mentioned McCullough vs Maryland....... Here's what it was about and the courts decision:     "The Issue: The case centered on the constitutionality of Congress's authority to create a national bank and whether states could tax it.  The Court's Decision: The Supreme Court, led by Chief Justice John Marshall, sided with McCulloch and the federal government. The Court ruled that Congress had the power to create the bank based on the Necessary and Proper Clause, which allows Congress to make laws necessary to carry out its enumerated powers.  Significance: McCulloch v. Maryland is a landmark case because it established the doctrine of implied powers, expanding the scope of federal authority and affirming the principle of federal supremacy. The decision reinforced the power of the federal government and helped define the relationship between state and federal governments."

Since chris keeps claiming "the union still had slavery/wanted to keep it" Connecticut: Like others, they adopted a gradual emancipation law in 1784. Eventually, by 1848 slavery was abolished. Kansas: Infamously, a hot topic whether it would be a slave state or a free state. They joined as a free state in 1861, and their constitution said that ‚Äú6. Slavery prohibited. There shall be no slavery in this state; and no involuntary servitude, except for the punishment of crime, whereof the party shall have been duly convicted.‚Äù  Washington DC: In 1862, Lincoln passed ‚ÄúAn Act for the Release of certain Persons held to Service or Labor in the District of Columbia‚Äù which banned slavery in the district. Also, the only reason this happened in the middle of the civil war was because no southern senators were in the house to oppose the bill. Therefore, it passed easily.  Pennsylvania: Adopted gradual emancipation via the ‚ÄúAn act for a gradual abolition of slavery‚Äù act passed in 1780. This act banned importation of slaves, required all slaves to be registered, and registered every born child as free, regardless of race. This meant eventually every slave was either freed or dead by the time of the civil war, and slavery was abolished. Vermont: Vermont abolished slavery via the constitution of their own country, as they were independent for a short while before joining the United States. Their 1777 constitution said ‚Äúno male person, born in this country, or brought from over sea, ought to be holden by law, to serve any person, as a servant, slave or apprentice, after he arrives to the age of twenty-one Years‚Ä¶‚Äù And their constitution was kept as the state constitution when they joined the United States, meaning slavery was banned before the 19th century and the industrial revolution in America. They also instated an act in 1858 that automatically freed any slave that reached Vermont.  Minnesota, Michigan, Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, and Wisconsin: When the northwest territory was acquired, slavery was banned in said territory. ‚ÄúThere shall be neither slavery nor involuntary servitude in the said territory, otherwise than in the punishment of crimes whereof the party shall have been duly convicted.‚Äù When each state was created from parts of this territory, they kept the banning of slavery in their constitution.  California: They joined as a state in 1850, and their constitution explicitly stated "...Neither Slavery nor involuntary Servitude, unless for the punishment of crimes, shall ever be tolerated in this State."  Nevada: They joined as a state in 1864, and their constitution stated ‚Äú‚Ä¶First. That there shall be in this state neither slavery nor involuntary servitude, otherwise than in the punishment for crimes, whereof the party shall have been duly convicted.‚Äù Louisiana: The emancipation proclamation already banned slavery in union-controlled parts of the state, but the union-controlled Louisiana abolished slavery in 1864 via the constitution. West Virginia: Shortly before the passage of the 13th amendment, west Virginia banned slavery on its own via the state legislature. Slavery was banned on February 3rd, 1865.  New York: A gradual abolition act like Pennsylvania‚Äôs was passed in 1799, and full emancipation happened in 1827, on July 5th. You can find this date labeled as ‚ÄúEmancipation Day‚Äù, which proves they abolished slavery. New Hampshire: An act stating that ‚ÄúNo person, because of decent, should be disqualified from becoming a citizen of the state.‚Äù Was passed in 1857 and fully implemented after the 13th amendment passing. Iowa: Joined as a free state in 1846. In article 1, section 23 of their constitution, they said: "There shall be no slavery in this State; nor shall there be involuntary servitude, unless for the punishment of crime. "

The Confederacy‚Äôs true purpose was to preserve and expand slavery, as made explicit in both their constitution and the declarations of secession by Confederate states.  Confederate Constitution Provisions Protecting Slavery  Article I, Section 9, Clause 4: "No bill of attainder, ex post facto law, or law denying or impairing the right of property in negro slaves shall be passed."  Prohibition of Emancipation: No Confederate state could outlaw slavery. This made slavery a permanent institution, showing the Confederacy‚Äôs primary goal was not states‚Äô rights but the preservation of slavery. Statements from Confederate Leaders  Alexander H. Stephens (Vice President of the Confederacy): In his "Cornerstone Speech" (1861):  "Our new government is founded upon exactly the opposite idea; its foundations are laid, its cornerstone rests, upon the great truth that the negro is not equal to the white man; that slavery‚Äîsubordination to the superior race‚Äîis his natural and normal condition."  Mississippi‚Äôs Declaration of Secession:  "Our position is thoroughly identified with the institution of slavery‚Äîthe greatest material interest of the world."  Georgia‚Äôs Declaration of Secession:  "For the last ten years we have had numerous and serious causes of complaint against our non-slave-holding confederate States with reference to the subject of African slavery."  Texas Declaration of Secession:  "We hold as undeniable truths that the governments of the various States... were established exclusively by the white race, for themselves and their posterity; that the African race had no agency in their establishment; that they were rightfully held and regarded as an inferior and dependent race."  While claiming to fight for the right to self-governance, the Confederate Constitution explicitly prohibited states from leaving the Confederacy:  Article I, Section 10, Clause 3: "No state shall, without the consent of the Congress, enter into any agreement or compact with another state or with a foreign power, or engage in war, unless actually invaded, or in such imminent danger as will not admit of delay."

Okay, so I‚Äôve been hearing some arguments floating around, and I want to address them because facts matter. Let‚Äôs break this down:  1. The Tenth Amendment Argument The Tenth Amendment gives powers not delegated to the federal government to the states, but it doesn‚Äôt mean states can do whatever they want‚Äîespecially if it violates basic human rights. The Confederacy claimed to fight for "states‚Äô rights," but let‚Äôs be real: the right they were fighting for was slavery. If the Confederacy truly cared about states' rights, they wouldn‚Äôt have made it illegal for a state to secede from the Confederacy once they joined. That hypocrisy speaks volumes about their real priorities.  2. "The Union Were the Traitors" This one‚Äôs wild. The Confederacy was literally a group of states that rebelled against the federal government to form their own nation. That‚Äôs the definition of treason. The Union, by contrast, fought to preserve the country as a whole. The Confederacy didn‚Äôt just leave‚Äîthey attacked first at Fort Sumter, starting the Civil War. The Union's fight wasn‚Äôt perfect, but labeling them as the traitors ignores who was trying to dismantle the U.S. entirely.  3. "The Parties Didn‚Äôt Switch" Oh, but they did. It wasn‚Äôt an overnight switch; it was gradual, spanning decades. Before the Civil Rights Movement, the Democratic Party had a stronghold in the South, largely made up of conservative, pro-segregation voters. But when Democratic leaders like President Lyndon B. Johnson pushed civil rights legislation in the 1960s, those Southern conservatives began shifting to the Republican Party, which used strategies like the "Southern Strategy" to appeal to their discontent. That‚Äôs why today, the South‚Äîa region once dominated by Democrats‚Äîis now a Republican stronghold, and the people most likely to defend the Confederacy tend to align with the GOP.  History is messy, but when you dig into the facts, the patterns become clear. It‚Äôs not about blaming one party or group‚Äîit‚Äôs about understanding how we got here so we can learn from it.

Hey everyone, so we had this intense history discussion in class today about the Confederacy and its roots in slavery, and I‚Äôve been thinking about it nonstop. First off, yes, slavery still exists in the world, and it‚Äôs as awful and inhumane now as it‚Äôs ever been. But the reason we focus so much on slavery in America‚Äîespecially when discussing the Confederacy‚Äîis because we‚Äôre analyzing our history and its lasting impact.  Something we dug into was how the Confederacy's constitution was eerily similar to the U.S. Constitution, except for the parts specifically protecting slavery. Yes, the Democrats were the party of slavery back then‚Äîbut the parties switched ideologies over time, especially during the Civil Rights Movement. It‚Äôs why today, the majority of people defending the Confederacy tend to align with the Republican Party. History is complicated, but that‚Äôs what makes it so fascinating to study.  Learning all this doesn‚Äôt make the past easier to grapple with, but it does make it clearer. Talking about this stuff can be uncomfortable, but it‚Äôs important. Gonna make a little list of northern slavery banning for chris, since he seems to have a misconception of this  -Pennsylvania: In 1780, they passed "An act for the gradual abolition of slavery" which slowly freed all slaves in the state. By the time of the civil war, there were practically no slaves. The details of this act prove that they were banning slavery  -New york: In 1799, they also passed an act based off of pennyslvania's.  It was also titled "An act for the gradual abolition of slavery" Eventually, in 1827, all slaves were freed.   -Vermont: When they were their own country, their constituion banned slavery. Article 1, section 1 said "Therefore, no male person, born in this country, or brought from over sea, ought to be holden by law, to serve any person, as a servant, slave, or apprentice..  When they joined the US, they kept the same constitution. Meaning slavery stayed banned.  -Northwest ordinance of 1787: This banned slavery in ohio, michigan, minnesoda, wisconsin, indiana, and illinois.  In article 6, it said: "There shall be neither slavery nor involuntary servitude in the [northwest] territory, otherwise than in the punishment of crimes whereof the party shall have been duly convicted..."  Already, 9 states have banned slavery. Which is far more than your claim, which is 0 states banning slavery. Let's keep going.  Iowa: Joined as a free state in 1846.  In article 1, section 23 of their constitution, they said: "There shall be no slavery in this State; nor shall there be involuntary servitude, unless for the punishment of crime. "  California: Again, joined as a free state in 1849. Their constitution stated "Neither slavery, nor involuntary servitude, unless for the punishment of crimes, shall ever be tolerated in this State." in article 1, section 18  I'll add the other states if chris acknowledges that at least half of the northern states clearly banned slavery

On one hand, "Secession for states' rights" doesn't necessitate that the states in question have a specific right in mind. Demanding the right to self-determination doesn't require that the person have a concrete idea of what determinations they want to make. I‚Äôm thrilled to share that I got my paper results back, and I PASSED! I dug deep into the reasons and timeline of the Great Party Switch and why it happened. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, shifts started with economic and regional influences. But the real turning point came during the Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s. The Democrats, originally more conservative in the South, began to push for civil rights, which didn‚Äôt sit well with many of their Southern supporters. The Republicans, meanwhile, adopted a "Southern Strategy" to appeal to disillusioned Democrats. Over time, these changes reshaped both parties. States right to do what?   Simple, the States right to leave the United States.   The States Rights to Own Slaves was NEVER challenged by the Federal Government or Northern States.  The Articles of Secession were filed in response to the Election Abraham Lincoln.  Abraham Lincoln did not run on a platform to END Slavery, he ran on a platform to formally end the Missouri Compromise that dictated the slave status of Westward Territories entry into Statehood.  Saying the South seceded because Lincoln wanted to end slavery, is a flat out lie.  Lincoln opposed any of the Western Territories from being added that had Slavery, and wanted the Western States south of the Mason Dixon to be added as Free States.   The South was really trying to protect the political power of slave states from being outnumbered by newly added free states.   Yes, Slavery WAS absolutely the central issue of contention, but it's not accurate, truthfull, factual or helpful to represent the Civil War in such a simplified matter as Slavery.   The cause of any war cannot be accurately simplified into a single word.   That's stupid.

0:50 I have no love for the Confederacy either, but this is extremely close-minded, and misses the concerns that are still relevant today. The phrase "state's rights" wasn't about what they wanted to use the rights for, it's referring to the 10th Amendment of the Constitution, which says "any power not explicitly given to the Federal government by the Constitution is reserved for the States, or the people." The southern states were arguing that the federal government was doing stuff they did not have authority to do, which did include outlawing slavery.  That's why the 13th amendment was ratified, to guarantee that the Federal government had the authority to enforce it. This is an incredibly valid concern, as dictatorships usually start by the government giving itself more power over time, and the US federal government has been doing exactly that quite a lot in recent decades. For obvious examples, look up how "emergency powers" are used.  edit: Apparently had to clarify that I am not defending the Confederacy, because people love making assumptions.

It‚Äôs important to understand that the South wasn‚Äôt being oppressed by taxes in the way it‚Äôs often portrayed. Back in the days before the Civil War, things like income taxes, property taxes, and sales taxes weren‚Äôt really a thing. When people talk about taxes back then, they‚Äôre referring to tariffs on imports, which is how the federal government made its money.  We actually have records from the time showing what foreign goods were imported into the U.S. Just before the war, the Chamber of Commerce of New York reported that from July 1859 to June 1860, New York alone brought in $233.7 million worth of foreign goods. Out of that, $203.4 million was subject to tariffs. In contrast, all other U.S. ports combined imported only $128.5 million, with $76.5 million subject to tariffs. This means that New York merchants paid 63.5% of all the federal government's revenue in that year.  This wasn‚Äôt a one-off occurrence‚ÄîNew York had been covering nearly two-thirds of the government's revenue for the previous five years as well. So, while the South might have felt that tariffs affected them, in reality, New York City was shouldering the majority of the financial burden, not the Southern states.  So no the South was not being oppressed by taxes

You do realize there were slaves in the North too, right? Even at the beginning of the Civil War. Few people, including Lincoln, made much of it early on. It wasn‚Äôt until about halfway through the war that slavery became a political tool‚Äîa morale boost to justify the mounting casualties. Yes, the war was about states‚Äô rights to have slaves, but the consequences of violating states‚Äô rights went far beyond just that issue. The real problem was that individual states lost the ability to govern independently, now forced to operate in lockstep with a centralized authority, no matter the circumstances or who was making the decisions.  Think about it: a distant group of politicians, far removed from the realities of your daily life, telling you and your state how to live. Sure, slavery was the immediate issue, but the broader principle is that the South was losing much more‚Äîthe autonomy of states and the precedent that the federal government could dictate whatever it wanted to any state, regardless of whether they understood or cared about the unique circumstances of that state. Slavery was wrong‚Äîno one denies the horrors or the moral imperative to end it‚Äîbut the way it was ended, through the federal government overriding states‚Äô autonomy, set a dangerous precedent that ripples through today.  The foundation of American culture is that states have the right to function independently from the federal government, specifically to avoid submission to centralized authority. Yes, the South had its share of racists, but dismissing their entire argument because of that fact is an ad hominem fallacy. Just because of who they were doesn‚Äôt invalidate their concerns about state sovereignty. Their argument was this: if the federal government can intervene in states‚Äô rights on the issue of slavery, what‚Äôs to stop it from intervening on any issue in the future? And while slavery absolutely needed to be abolished, the South‚Äôs concern about the dangers of unchecked federal power still holds water and reflects how the nation was originally intended to function.  If that precedent was allowed to stand, it means the federal government could impose its will on any state, north, south, east, or west, whenever it wanted and for whatever reason it deemed fit. So while slavery was the immediate issue, the bigger picture was about the future of how this country would be governed.

It's very simple: If states' rights was more important to the Confederacy than slavery, then logically, Confederate states would have the right to ban slavery if they wanted, right? But Article I Section 9(2) of the Confederate Constitution explicitly forbade states from passing any laws banning or impairing slavery. So when the Confederacy measured slavery against states' rights to not allow slavery, they chose preserving slavery at the expense of states' rights.  Case closed.

I would recommend "historythatdoesntsuck" podcast for anyone wanting to learn more slavery was always deeply rooted since the USA was founded
As someone from Pennsylvania, I grew up hearing that the Civil War was about Slavery and that the North were the "good guys" and the South were the "bad guys". As I grew up, I actually began reading history. One of the first things that comes up is realizing that the North's conduct during the war alone throws the idea of "good guys" and "bad guys" into the trash. I won't detail all of it here, but  to cover just a few things, the North engaged at various times, in campaigns that included the deliberate and systematic rape of entire cities full of women and the execution of civilian children. After this realization, I still continued my reading. In short - there's no logically sound argument that the war was over slavery.  Firstly, it's rather clear that the North never initiated the war to end slavery. The war went on for nearly 2 years before the emancipation proclamation was released. If the war was about Slavery, this seems an awfully late time in the war to finally make any serious statement about the central issue at hand. Clearly, the North was not motivated by the desire to end slavery.   On the other side, you have the issue of concretely showing that the Confederacy was actually concerned about an end to slavery. This is one of the central problems in the argument. Maryland, Missouri, and Kentucky throw a wrench into the idea that the Confederacy was formed to defend Slavery. Maryland, a state with relatively few slaves, was strongly in favor of the Confederacy. If not for early occupation by the Union, Maryland absolutely would have joined the Confederacy. On the other hand, you have Kentucky and Missouri. Both of these states had huge numbers of slaves and both of these states overwhelmingly voted against secession. On a much smaller level, the county level votes in many states further cause confusion. In Tennessee for example, the counties of Eastern Tennessee that had the most slaves, were also the most Pro-Union. The more mountainous counties, those on the border of South & North Carolina, were strongly Pro-Confederate, but had very low slave populations, both in absolute numbers and per-capita. If the war was about slavery, why were some of the areas with the greatest density of slaves so Pro-Union and vice versa?  The second issue is the timeline. If the issue was slavery, why did the war happen when it did? It should be noted, that according to John C. Calhoun, the man that lead the pro-secessionist movement in South Carolina, the chief concern was Lincoln's proposed additional tariffs on Southern States. Mr. Calhoun, had previously led such calls when tariffs were proposed, such as the 1832 Ordinance of Nullification. The tariffs proposed by Lincoln inspired South Carolina to secede, as they had already threatened to do in the past. Even after South Carolina's Ordinance of Secession, the war didn't break out. Even after the South Carolina militia shelled Fort Sumter, the war didn't break out. In fact, immediately after news of this broke many Southern politicians, who would shortly be pivotal in the creation of the Confederacy, condemned South Carolina for doing this. So what caused the other Southern states to secede? In late December of 1860, Lincoln announced his intention to form an Army of 30,000 men in Washington DC and march or sail it to South Carolina to round up the South Carolina legislature and place the entire state under Federal control. To many on both sides of the Mason-Dixon line, the movement of a federal Army through multiple states without permission (a right they believed protected by the 3rd amendment) and to use that army against the freely elected legislature of a state was unthinkable. It was this announcement that inspired many of the early Confederate states to hold conventions to discuss potential courses of action. Even after the creation of the Confederacy in February of 1861, the war really wouldn't begin for another 5 months in July of 1861, 8 months after the initial shelling of Fort Sumter. The problem with the timeline is that slavery doesn't fit into it anywhere. The most proximal cause of the Civil War, demonstrably, is the Lincoln's threat to invade South Carolina. Without that, the Confederacy would never have formed. Zooming out, the most chronic cause of the Civil war was a disagreement regarding the powers of the Federal versus the State. We can see that pretty clearly in Calhoun's 1832 Ordinance of Nullification and the Bank War (which was mostly divided along North/South lines). If we zoom even further out we can see the infantile divisions that would form into the Civil War at the earliest days of our country. The Federalist/Anti-Federalist divide can also be seen along geographic lines. To have the view that the war was caused by slavery, you have to completely ignore the most proximal causes of the war as well as the decades long cracks that had been growing ever wider. Saying that the Civil War was about Slavery is comparable to saying that the American Revolution was caused by taxes on Tea. Yes, it was an issue, but it wasn't the proximal issue that actually caused regular people to take to the streets with guns and it wasn't the long-term issue that created the powder keg of animosity ultimately resulting in either conflict.  The American Civil War is complicated. Slavery certainly played a part, but a much, much smaller one than many people would like. If the war were about slavery, it makes for a nice clean story of "good guys" and "bad guys" where the good guys just so happen to win. These sort of stories are really easy to tell children and are easy for adults to swallow. The unfortunate reality is that there weren't good guys and bad guys. The motivations of both sides are gray. Both sides have admirable qualities. The North at it's best was fighting to preserve the Union that so many had worked and died to build. At it's worst, the Union Army was packed full of rapists, sadistic murderers, war criminals, and more. This exact same Army would later go on to carry out genocidal campaigns against the Plains Indians just a few short years after the Civil War. The South, at it's best, was trying to preserve the original intention of the founding of this nation. They were working to protect the rights of States against federal over reach. At its worst, it was also a nation that kept millions of men and women in bondage. It's worth saying that all of these things can be true simultaneously.  Ultimately it's a really complex picture, but it's a more truthful one and one supported by reality.   In some ways, the Civil War parallels the Eastern Front in WWII. The Nazis were bad, but the Soviets were honestly worse. Does that mean that I'm Pro-Nazi? No, but  I think it's wrong to shut my eyes and completely ignore what the Soviet Union was doing  before, during, and after the war just because they opposed the Nazis. In the real world, both sides can be bad and both sides can be good.

To be fair slavery wasn't the only reason. There is more to the Civil War than just one side fighting to protect slavery and the other not wanting to give it up. There were social and political differences between North and South which formed the attitude each side had for each other. There were also economic issues besides slavery such as the federal government imposing protectionist tariffs on agricultural goods produced in the South such as cotton to stymie their sale to foreign merchants so that domestic manufacturing can then take them for their own productions and profit. That's not to say there is no rational argument that the war was over slavery. You could try making the argument that secession was over slavery but the war was over Northern dominance over the south.

Most laws made leading up to their secession heavily favored the South because that's where the raw materials came from. For example, there was a law that for every slave state entered into the union, a free state was entered. So one of the free states was Utah, the slave state entered as its counterpart was Texas. The South also dominated the presidency as they counted slaves as half a person but wouldn't let them vote, making southern states more powerful in the electoral college without having the divide of different opinions. I'm no lost-causer.  However, the Civil War was initially started, from the Northern Perspective, over the reunification of the Southern States back with the Northern States. Whereas with the Southern states hitherto Slavery being a serious issue, more specifically the issue of equitable statehood becoming problematic, as it was an immensely important aspect to equitable Electoral College and Election processes for both sides, and saw that the Abolitionist/Emancipationist Movement was trying to, essentially, force them into a corner where they could no longer vote with sufficient power. After all, the 3/5ths Clause and the Slave/Free State Clause were two major compromises to avoid Civil War in the first place, per the Founding Fathers. To Lincoln, it was an egregious breach of national security, one that was clear with regards to France and England's interests who saw an opportunity with the Confederacy. Potentially increased influence in the Americas since the Monroe Doctrine was put into effect nearly 50 years or so prior, and also the decreased political, social, and military power of a rapidly growing, industrializing and territorially expanding nation.  One could also argue that it was a war over industrialization itself. As the North was proving that people weren't at all free, just beheld to a different form of slavery not unlike that of the Confederacy. But as opposed to picking Cotton, they were working machinery and living in crowded sky scraping apartments for meager wages.   The Confederacy's reasoning behind the Slave Ownership rights was due to the fact that Emancipation was considered on an equitable footing as Abolitionism. Right or wrong, it should be stated also that Abolitionism was not a popular sentiment in the Northern States either. Individuals like Chamberlain and his brother are rarities in the enormity of the whole that was the Union Army. As comparison, Lee, prior to the Emancipation Proclamation, upon inheriting his Father-In-Law's vast wealth and slave holdings, gave freedom to the slaves of his own volition (this does not justify Lee as a Traitor... But it does show that its not, in fact, black and white), whereas his right hand man (General Jackson) was an adamant slave owner... On the reverse, Grant himself owned 3 slaves, and his wife, back deep in the northern states, owning a vast slew of slaves, was an outspoken pro-Slavery individual.  Granted, the very debate of Slavery was immense between the two states, and some of the most outspoken Abolitionists, ironically, hailed from Slave States (Henry Cassius Clay being one of the more potent individuals, who himself essentially strong armed Lincoln into passing Emancipation Proclamation in 1863, and actively assisted as Ambassador to Russia, in requesting that they should warn Britain and France that they would declare war if they became directly involved in the American Civil War). And for the entirety of the US' history, at that point, Slavery was oft the argument that led to heated debates.  Yet, he was fighting for a Nation that, from modern perspective, was a conflict solely derivative of the Abolition of Slavery.  Again, individuals like John Brown were not popular. To much of the main stream Republicans in the North, he was a radical who was trying to spark an unnecessary war, not a freedom fighter trying to inspire a libertarian revolt against the Slave Owner Class.  For many in the common ranks (who were neither slave, nor slave owner, on both sides of the war), they were fighting for their respective state, and viewed the other as a tyrant (Confederate Enlisted) and a rebel (Union Enlisted), the ramifications of the political issues were predominantly held at the higher levels. For the common man fighting, the Slave was a non-issue because neither could own slaves (financially or socially) in the grand scheme of things.  The issue of slavery, and Emancipation Proclamation, came to a head for two-fold purpose: A) To deprive the South of any meaningful value in its slavery (as the EP only addresses those states in Rebellion. It did not address Emancipation for those who, being grandfathered in by by-law or loophole, in Northern or otherwise non-rebel territories, were otherwise slaves) and thus hope to reduce its manpower and any legal precedent, while also giving Union Commanders Legal Jurisdiction to free and provide safe conduct to slaves found in the South, to the North...  B) To reduce the political, social, military and economic ties between the Confederacy and Britain and France, whom both had Abolished Slavery near 30 years prior in 1836 and 1833 respectively. By doing so, it sets a global stage statement of the American Civil War from one of reunification, to that of Emancipation and Abolition as well. To Lincoln, Slavery, again, was a non-issue, recently found documents of his penning found that he was not the "Great Emancipator" that we once thought, this all being found by contemporary Historians and edifying that he was not as adamant on Slavery as he was presumed to have been. In point of fact, the Emancipation Proclamation was more a political repositioning, rather than a moral stance of absolutism. In one of his various diaries, he states that in any capacity to which the South could keep their slaves, but reunify with the Union, he would do it.  He also actively worked to try and find new home and nation for the Emancipated Slaves, knowing full well that their integration into society would be consequentially marked with a perpetual issue of racial and cultural conflict. And even actively worked with the British Prime Minister, at the time, to find them a new home so that the Confederate losers would not have any power, authority, or political weaponizing of the post-War issues that were sure to be wrought. He also understood that the North, already suffering under the immense immigration of Irish, Slavic and Mediterranean nationals into the US seeking new hearth and keep, were not going to be fans of seeing the already difficult industrial jobs disappear to individuals who would work for a fraction of the price, at twice the amount of labor (their position was unfounded, of course, because much of the Emancipated Slaves never moved north in the first place). Even more so, especially to the Emancipators, to release, outright, the amount of individuals who are either uneducated or undereducated (thanks to the Confederates) would be even more disastrous than that of keeping them in their Slavery.  While the Abolitionists are Morally Correct in their position, to outright demand the emancipation without a Policy Solution to deal with the aftermath of their freedom, especially when we see nearly 100 years of Racially Motivated Jim Crow Social Warfare against the Black Community by the Democrats, now reversed into "Benevolent Tyranny" by keeping them on the Welfare and Social Programs Plantations they've carefully cultivated in the last 60 years, proving that Abolitionism was a correct choice, but did not venture to seek out aftermath programs and protections to prevent such backlash, post-Civil War...  Conclusion: The Civil War was not JUST about Slavery. There were many other issues that eventually led to the American Civil War. But the greatest of them, at the forefront, was Slavery at the higher levels of Politics...

Honestly, I can understand where the Confederacy itself was coming from, but honestly I think they would be ashamed of their modern-day sympathizers for pretending like slavery wasn't the issue. I mean... their perspective is actually really simple, no matter how unpalatable it is to modern people. The British tried to offer slaves freedom for fighting against the revolutionaries, and this was a reason why the South originally sided with the Union. They were, in fact, promised they could keep them if they sided with the revolution, and that the issue would be left to the states and they'd be given autonomy in this regard. You can argue that this was immoral and the British were in the right, you can argue that it's fine for it to be null and void because it was an immoral agreement in the first place, etc... but it's hard to argue that the Southern slaveholders were wrong to feel that the US had stabbed them in the back by working to end slavery, since it was in fact their support that helped the US become independent.   If it's hard to understand how people could fight for slavery, well... just imagine that we elected someone from PETA president and they forced the farmers to give up all their farm animals with no compensation. Wouldn't those people be angry and up in arms, and then maybe future generations brainwashed by PETA propaganda wouldn't understand how those barbarians ate meat, used animals for work, and kept pets in their homes, etc. Or imagine if communists took over the government and said it was immoral for an individual to own a home, and suggested that real estate shouldn't be anyone's property and all land should be owned in common and used for the good of the people?   If you can imagine getting mad about either of those things, or both of them, then it shouldn't be that hard to understand how someone could defend slavery... you wouldn't feel upset if you invested good money in livestock and then had PETA tell you you're not allowed to have it anymore and you won't be compensated because we've decided that's not okay anymore and you're evil? You wouldn't feel upset if you were a landlord and then the communists call you bourgeoise and say the property you've been maintaining isn't yours because owning property and profiting from it is evil? Like... can people not put aside their disgust for two minutes to understand their perspective without pretending like it was about something else, seriously?

Oh ooooh, I took APUSH so I'm slightly qualified to give a somewhat decent answer: it's complicated. There were a lot of reasons why the Civil War happened though slavery is the biggest reason, just not in the way you'd think.   You see, the northern states focused on industry and trade while the southern states focused on farming. Coming off of the industrial revolution, the north had a massive glowup while the south was relatively the same. Each side played to their strengths to make the most money possible, but the use of slavery in the south didn't reflect well on the country seeing as slavery was kinda falling out of fashion (so to speak) with the main European nations. So the north wanted to demolish slavery, partially to improve trade and partially to undermine the south and gain greater politcal power overall. The south meanwhile had very little industry and couldn't really get rid of slavery without crippling their economy.  Side note: I don't condone slavery nor do I want to necessarily paint the south in the best light. They definitely would've also try to take more power from the north if the situation was reversed. Doesn't change the fact that the union didn't really do a lot to help the south after the war nor try to prevent the war in the first place. Both sides were at fault and the union shouldn't get pity points for stopping slavery when they went about it in the worst way possible.   Also that's just barely scratching the surface of the how and why of the Civil War. Nobody had good intentions, none of them were heroes, none of them were villains, and the majority of the Confederate soldiers were just poor farmers brought into a war they didn't ask for. Just like thousands of conflicts in human history.

It was *entirely* about forcing the entire country to condone living under a ruling class that outright owned the bulk of the working class.  All of those other entirely legitimate points of friction, like the cultural and social differences between North and South were all underpinned by the fact that the Northern colonies (and then states) were by and large founded largely as classless societies, (or at least with no rigid class society) insular religious communities of extremist sects exiled from their European homelands, and for profit private and government sponsored enterprises that relied on maritime economies focused on the manufacture and trade of luxury and consumer goods sold to Europe, as the land and weather was too poor to produce cash crops. Slavery did exist for a time in all of them, but over time, even as far south as Pennsylvania, that slavery was not viable in the north. But the South was largely founded by second sons of the European landed nobility, sponsored by the crown to essentially create the feudalistic holdings that they would otherwise be denied as inheritances, as preference would go to their older brothers. The only way for these men to leave the shadows of the their brothers, and hold title to significant parcels of land, was to strike out into the frontier, and settle a farm, carbon copy the rigid feudalistic class structures they left behind in Europe, but with African slaves instead of European serfs; sine none of the serfs got permission to leave from their respective lords, and despite being considered a lesser race, africans had a reputation for being duteous and competent workers. (which sounds like they would actually have been the greater race, but unpacking the cognitive dissonance of racism is just too extra to do here.) Anyway, because they were black, and not white, locking people and their descendants into perpetual bondage was considered more enlightened by some at the time. By the 1830s, it was already evident that these two societies were entirely incompatible with each other over the long term, as one encouraged people to advance society by advancing their own position, and entrepreneurism and self motivation were encouraged, as long as they improved living conditions for the whole community, while the other would have collapsed entirely if those traits had been condoned, as it would mean rebellious slaves, and maybe even worse, lower to middle class whites with enough self drive to make a name and fortune that eclipsed their plantation owning employers. It wasn't an accident that with enough money or slaves, you could be entirely exempt from being drafted to fight in the CSA army, without even having to pay for a waiver (in the north anyone could get out of the draft, but they had to pay for a waiver.) This is exactly parallel to the fact that State flags from Northern former colony states, are typically "Union Blue" and feature a state or colonial seal, used to represent the state as a whole in an official capacity, but Southern states like Maryland use flags that copies a *Personal* coat of arms of Cecil Calvert (Royally appointed) Baron of Baltimore (1605-1675) The District of Columbia's flag (used to be part of a slave state)  Is George Washington's personal coat of arms; while Florida and Alabama, fly flags that directly reference Bourbon cross, which was the coat of arms of the Spanish Monarchs that originally funded those colonies.  In all cases of which, the first waves of European settlers included enslaved persons and indentured servants."

You're not wrong in how you feel, Doobus Goobus.  What kills me is how people ONLY focus on Slavery and act like Lincoln was some kind of Hero.  There is no argument that he did the right thing but it was for ALL THE WRONG REASONS!  Even when he got into office, he didn't give a crap about Slavery and said that it as States' Rights.  (What's this? A Politician going back on his campaign promises?  What a shock!)  "I have no purpose, directly or in-directly, to interfere with the institution of slavery in the States where it exists.  I believe I have no lawful right to do so, and I have no inclination to do so." - Excerpt from paragraph 2 of Lincoln's First Message to the U.S. Congress, penned July 4, 1861.  What was the spark for Secession was the Morrill Tax passed that same session.  "My policy seeks only to collect the Revenue, (a 40 percent federal sales tax on imports to Southern States under the Morrill Tariff Act of 1861)." - Excerpt from paragraph 5 of Lincoln's First Message to the U.S. Congress, penned July 4, 1861.  While 40% seemed harsh, it made sense.  He was more or less taxing them for using slave labor.  However, this Morrill Tariff Act went overboard.  It made it so that the South could sell ONLY to the Northern States eight months out of the year where they were to be taxed 40% of the sales to but ALSO from the North... and to top it off, when they COULD sell internationally, the Morril Tax charged them for **50%** of the going value!  However, the Harshness could have worked if not for one certain thing: it was truly a one-sided Tax that was passed in a one-sided fashion  The Morrill Tax was founded by Vermont Congressman Justin Morrill and the Northern States unanimously pushed it through on March 2, 1861.  A Tax that only effects the Southern States.  Needless to say, this pissed off he South with them citing the violation of their Constitutional Right of, "No Taxation Without Representation".  So of course, the seceded, which was also a Constitutional Right...  ...Constitutional Rights which President Lincoln decided to deny by going back on his original apathy for Slavery and deciding to frame the Civil War with the Moral Justification of, "FREEING THE SLAVES!"  It was never just about Slavery.  It was about Free Enterprise on both sides of the divide.  As usual, things only got better and human suffering was ended when someone could profit over it.  Truly, it was a dark time where there were NO good people and laws and proper conduct on both sides ignored over stubbornness, pride, and wealth.
The greater irony is that, at its peak, the Confederacy had a larger, more powerful federal government than the Union did at the time.  So the whole state's rights argument really falls flat when confronted with that fact.
You see it's real simple: violating basic human rights is one thing, but interfering with states rights, now that's just unacceptable.

In all honesty, both the states rights excuse and even slavery itself aren't the real root of why the confederacy was formed. This is going to make it sound mundane but this actually makes it worse than slavery being the focus. Slavery was a means to an end. The real issue was that the south had no industrial or commercial base for their economy. The south was pretty much entirely dependent on agriculture and the staples produced like cotton. However this agricultural system hinged on the cheap labor of the slaves (whether or not slaves were paid, money was still needed to give them what they needed to live) to the point that NOT having slaves would have crashed the southern economy.  Don't get me wrong, slavery is evil. The core issue was State‚Äôs Rights but the immediate Right in question was in regard to slavery. To say it was about State‚Äôs Rights and not slavery or vice versa are both incorrect. It was about both and for people to say otherwise is incredibly ignorant and don‚Äôt understand the nuance of the issue and the mindset of the society of that time period. If your argument is it was about slavery and NOT State‚Äôs rights, then you just look just as foolish as the people who say it was about State‚Äôs Rights and NOT about slavery. It was about both and given the culture at that time, it didn‚Äôt make the South evil, just woefully ignorant of changing societal norms and outdated beliefs based on abhorrent practices heavily rooted into their economy. By no means am I defending slavery, but even Lincoln himself didn‚Äôt see the South as his enemy and wanted nothing more than restore the Union and put an end to this petty squabble. The only thing evil about the South were the wealthy plantation owners who had the power and money to sway legislators to continue lobbying for slavery to continue so their wealth wouldn‚Äôt be threatened by changing societal norms. Racism was quite prevalent in throughout the United States, though it was more prevalent in the south due to slavery being so deeply entwined with the more heavily agricultural Southern States. There was actually a lot more to it than just slavery, but in the end the argument just loops around back to slavery.  Slavery is a mode of production. Modes of productions (or "ways of producing") are a combination of the productive forces (think labor power) and the means of production (think tools, machinery, infrastructure, materials, exploitable resources, etc.) and of course everything else that goes into it; property, power and control relations governing said means of production, and a bunch of other shit you wouldn't care about.   Slaves were considered private property - technically personal property - though this is to be expected as personal property and private property have fused together to virtually mean the same thing by that point and today. Slavery was an extremely outdated mode of production even at the time; for reference a 'slave society' (as mentioned above) is intended to be followed by feudalism and then capitalism.  Like all systems which exploit the labor power of others, those who benefit from it despise any amount of their profits being taken from them unless they can be assured they will be reimbursed for it somehow almost immediately. Henceforth one can raise in such a society where private ownership over the means of production was so common that "If they abolish this private property [slaves] then they're going to abolish ALL private property!"... of course a laughable concept considering America was founded on the concept. But yes, it was about slavery; just with a couple asterisks at the end.
0:40 not defending the confederacy here, but a small correction: lincoln never said explicitly that he was going to abolish slavery for most of the first half of his presidency, to avoid stirring controversy with the slave states which were still in the union (maryland, delaware, kentucky, and missouri). he specifically stated that the war was over bringing the union back, which was a smart move on his part because, for one, he kept the border states in the union, but for two, he decreased the sectionalism which had contributed to the conflict in the first place (there were suddenly union-sympathizers in the south, and slave-sympathizers in the north). though it was clear that lincoln would at some point have to abolish slavery, he never explicitly said that he would during his election, and the south seceded the moment he was elected. the issue of secession was thus largely political, but like all things civil war, still heavily tied into slavery. at this point everything political was a slavery issue since the parties were literally defined on varying positions of slavery.
Even as a Brit i know it was more complicated than that, basically the North wanted to remove slavery as everyone knows, but the Southern states would've been economically ruined having relied on slave labour, something that was legal up until that point.  An equivalent would be being against child labour, but then buying a new pair of Nike trainers
Although slavery was undoubtedly the biggest piece in the states rights arguement, the Confederacy basically wanted states rights to manage their own economy. Economy was the big picture in this part of American history. The south felt that they were being taxed unfairly, they believed that giving the federal government more power would lead to the same situation they had when they were just colonies to the British, they believed that a national bank and internal improvements would only help the north as well.  Economically speaking, the south at the time was only able to make a good amount of money by producing cotton and selling to European nations. This ties into the invention of the cotton gin and how slavery was the south's way of gaining labor. Another thing was that the north and the south were economically disconnected. At the time, the western frontier was where farms were, which with the use of internal improvements, it would connect the north and the west. The south also seceded from the union because even though the North didnt want to end slavery but rather stop its expansion to new states, they forsaw this as the North's way to slowly get rid of whats economically important to them. Sorry for the large read.

Southern culture goes much far back than 1861-1865. Beginning with the Spanish in Florida and Texas in the 16th Century- possibly earlier. They held the first Thanskgiving (Catholic mass and feast) in St. Augustine and El Paso. And Southern states didn't secede because of "slavery". They seceded for two reasons: a) they were self-sufficient to do so  b)the North and federal government weren't abiding by the Constitution as it was written at the time. There's nothing in the Constitution that prohibits secession. It is silent on that issue. It simply states that a state or territory cannot enter into any alliance, confederation or compact with another state, foreign power, etc. while a member of the United States. It has to be approved by Congress. However, once states or territories declare their independence, they are no longer bound by the Constitution. So the Confederates were not traitors. One of the largest investors in Southern Plantations, btw, was the Bank of New York. Well till the end of 1865. New Jersey didn't abolish slavery until January 1866. yeah the states' rights bit is goofy, the proper argument is that it was over ecomomic issues that included slavery, but also tariffs among a handful of other issues. the answer to "States' rights to what" is the states' rights to secede if they come to believe that the union was detrimental to their interests, in this case the north slowly trying to phase out the backward southern economic system which was based on agricultural slave labor. so the answer to "what was the civil war about" is "it was sorta slavery, sorta not, but at the same time sorta was, there were a lot of boring socio-economic and political factors but no matter what way you spin it, by virtue of the southern economy and society of the time slavery was most certainly associated with most of the reasons you could propose for trying to secede"
To answer your question, it's the States' right to secede. That's what the Civil War was fought over. The US Government did not believe States had the right to leave the Union, and so they fought a war to prevent that from happening. The North didn't even propose the abolition of slavery until two years into the war in order to bolster public and international support. Up until the Emancipation Proclamation, both sides were fighting for a South where slavery would still exist; one as part of the Union and one as an independent country.

It was also another part due to the cultural divide between the North and the South as I stated before. Ok, i want to preface that slavery is awful and terrible and should never be done again. But i also want to say why southerners feel so strongly about the confederacy.   First thing you need to understand is how slavery is used in different cultures. As my history teacher put it, among slave owning societies, there are those with slaves, and those that are built on slavery.   For example, imagine the world exactly as it is, except rideshare apps are at no monetary cost. Uber, lyft, those electric bikes and scooters, all of them. The catch is, a dog dies everytime you use it. It is a random dog, but was a family pet, and you see a picture of it along with its name and the crying family.  But you can easily avoid this by just not using a rideshare app. Use a normal taxi, walk, take a train, call a friend, etc. There are other options that are easy to access. That is a society with slaves. Sure it sucks, but is pretty limited overall and easy to overcome/remove  A society BUILT on slavery operates as if that dog premise applied everytime you or anyone else got onto the internet for any reason. Looking up directions, cooking tips, questions, anything. The internet is integral to modern society and applies in places you may not expect, like inside your car or gaming systems. Some people have alarm clocks with an internet connection. So is the answer to boycott the internet? Would companies destroy their own infrastructure because it was the right thing to do? Could you seriously keep your job without internet access at all? How would you pay rent? All banks are online now, at some point a dog is dying expressly for the purpose of you getting your money, even if you get it in cash.  For the south, slavery was pretty much all encompassing. It was a vital part of their economy and way of life. It was an absolutely disgusting practice but one that everybody in the system absolutely depended on. At some point, every good or product passed through a slaves hands in the south before you bought it  And what about the small scale? For the confederacy, they were fighting to keep slavery. For the confederate soldiers, many were fighting for their way of life and their families who depended on it. They were by no means innocent of wrongdoing, many if not all practicing racism in a time where it was rapidly decreasing and being disproved as a virtue in almost any rational debate, but they went out to fight and die in hopes that their family wouldnt suffer a great depression and starvation as a result.  Again, the confederacy was built off of evil ideals, but every confederate was a person with their own priorities, fears, and virtues. They were just on the wrong side of history and the wrong side of the war. Had they been born in the north, they may have been exactly the same for all we know.

"States rights to do what?"   This is a question asked by people who have absolute no idea what they're discussing and think it is some sort of gotcha when abolition began in the south and slavery began in the North. WHen the Northern Slave Ports were massive and the North was some of the last states to abolish slavery. States rights refers to governance structure. During the founding of America the original government after the Contintental Congress, was the Confederacy of America which George Washington was the last president of before switching to the Federal System.   The Federal system was agreed upon under promises that its powers would not be abused and states rights, IE States abilities to set their own laws and govern their own territories was to be protected. Prior to the "civil war" the federal government had engaged in overreach after overreach. This combined with a cutlural divide between the North who initially wanted to suceed from the South and the South who succeeded after Lincoln was elected without the Southern Delegation.  Anyone who tries to defend the North is entirely ignorant of history. Not only did they have slaves, they didn't free any during the war. The Emancipation proclamation only freed slaves in foreign territory. Occupied territory would not see any slaves freed. Prior to the war the black population of the South was 4 million. After the war the population thanks to the long march to the sea and the Norths hatred of black people, the population was reduced to 3 million. Of the remaining 3 million only 300,000 went northword, many of whom had helped the Northern Army and would have faced persecution by their own communities. Another portion was for states rights, rights as in to where each state could vote on a law differently opposed to a central government to affect them all, these rights were largely not for slavery (I say largely, as a portion did do it for slavery, mainly the folk who had slaves fought for it) The USA wanted a centralized government with little states rights, and the CSA wanted more of a state centered government. He still absolutely hated slavery, and wanted to end it, but he also wanted to preserve the union, the compromise he thought of was that if he stops the supply of slaves, it will die out naturally. Don't think many people understand the "state's rights" argument. States are meant to act as their own thing, and, for the most part, not be influenced by other states unless what they're doing is deemed unconstitutional. The only argument I'll give isn't a defense against the confederacy rather an indictment against the union. The war wasn't about the immoral nature of it, but rather the economic issue. Many of the north thought the large plantations with their slave labor would overtake their slave-free production and effectively run them out of business. Abe Lincoln was one of the few speaking out against the immoral nature of slavery, but he only wanted to stop the expansion of slavery so that the practice would eventually die out on its own. Thankfully John Brown, a fucking brilliant mad-man and a hero, forced his hand by raiding an armory with a group of people, freeing slaves, arming them, and continuing south creating an uprising.    TL:DR The Union didn't care about the moral nature of it for the majority of conflict, and the war only happened because a great man had a crazy plan and terrible execution.

Nice strawman. It‚Äôs actually way more nuanced in both directions.   To be fair the north/union actually was pretty oppressive to the south (they once sent an entire battalion into a town and stole all their clothes/took their food) but thats only part of the issue. The issue is that ultimately the white southerners who suffered both before and after the war was the non-wealthy, non-slave owning whites.   Before the war they couldn‚Äôt compete with slaves for labor meaning entire families of white peoples would often starve in desolate, grinding poverty. However the alternative was the abusive, aggressive industrialized north whom, after the war was over, began a campaign of terror against average white southerners that we today call ‚ÄúReconstruction‚Äù.   This is the irony. Very few former slave owners were particularly harmed throughout the post-war period because they were wealthy elites. The ones whom were most harmed were just regular working people. Throughout this period regular white southerners had their land taken from them, had vengeful former-slaves put in charge of law and local politics, were heavily taxed, robbed, and generally were violated extensively.  The average southerner, without whom the war would not have happened and for whom in fact slavery was economically destructive, didn‚Äôt fight to defend slavery they fought to defend themselves from oppression. So when they lost they were thus oppressed.   It actually gets even more complicated when you look at just how economically harmful slavery was to working whites and the specific methods that those same average whites were punished after the war.    So yeah. When people say ‚Äúit wasn‚Äôt just about slavery‚Äù they are being earnest because to the average confederate soldier it really wasnt. True fact! Since the Confederacy was so shit at everything, even their money was literally physically shitty: it was made with usually _rice_ paper, signed with iron ink (so it rusted within the week), and usually had been cut out with scissors. Well, one man by the name of Samuel Upham, in 1862, started making fake Confederate dollars. Mind you, he owned a proper printing press facility, so they were spot on, and using higher quality paper (and possibly the Secretary of War of the USA, Stanton, maaaaayyyyyyyyy have slipped him some legit linen paper, as per proper USD, later)-- he did print his name and address on the bottom edge, noting that he was making them as souvenirs. He took an actual $5 Confederate note and made 3,000 copies of it, which he sold for a penny each. In a matter of days, his supply had sold out.  Later, he heard that smugglers were just cutting _off_ the part with his dox, and using it to buy southern cotton. Since his copies were _better_ than the actual confederate bills, the southerners took them hook, line, and sucker: the North got cotton, and the South got _even worse_ runaway inflation (than they were already suffering). By  the end, he made a million and a half fake bills, for a "value" of _fifteen million_ Confederate dollars, while making an actual profit of $50,000-- which is roughly like making $1.4 million dollars today.

The primarily Northern federal government was heavily dependent on import tariffs to fund their agendas (this is pre-income tax). These import taxes fell primarily on the South, whose agrarian economy didn't lend much to self-sufficiency. As the North increased tariffs, life became harder for middle and lower class Southerners and foreign nations retaliated by imposing tariffs on things like Southern cotton and tobacco. The North didn't give a shit, because protectionism and cheap immigrant labor granted them an unparalleled degree of industrial self-sufficiency their Southern countrymen couldn't afford.  Most Southerners didn't own slaves and, furthermore, resented the Planter Class who possessed most of them, given that slavery made things hard for free contractors and tradesmen who were out-competed by slave labor. That being said, there's no reason for them to fight over slavery, especially when Lincoln himself said he'd happily abide it if the Union might be preserved. The South seceded because an increasingly centralized, more politically populous North was crushing their economy and looking down upon them as social pariahs (for matters independent of slavery, for the North was just as racist as the South was).

Here's the actual problem that people ignore. "Reconstruction" Which was anything but. You see, the institution of slavery was evil. Because slaves were never given any education and were all illiterate, and had no concept of financial management, they were completely unemployable. This is why many, many slaves opted to stay on the plantations they were already living on before the civil war. Now here's the real problem, most of the slaves that were free'd fucking starved to death during "reconstruction" because the economy of the South has basically fist fucked into oblivion by Shermans march and various economic policies that made industrialization of the south extremely difficult. This effectively caused a 20 year long famine that forced many people, white and black (but mostly black) into eating dirt (I'm not being hyperbolic, literal geophagy). Literal millions of former slaves starved to death and many more became sick and ill as a result of the federal governments policies and actions, much of which were implemented to "punish" the people of the South (civilians shouldered nearly the full burden of this punishment). This is in addition to the over half a million people that needlessly died in the actual war itself. With the perfection of hindsight, here is what should have happened. A gradual phase out, which is ironically what much of the Confederacy wanted, over the span of about 20 to 30 years. Steam tractors were inevitably going to make slavery obsolete anyway (machines make for far better slaves than humans, much more dependable, reliable, and infinitely more obedient). Additionally, the plantation owning familial dynasties were particularly egregious. They were more often than not the rich factions within the confederacy that wanted to keep it institutionalized forever, much to the dismay of the white sharecroppers (slavery depresses the wages of working men) who were a vast majority of the actual population.  So whats the lesson? Slavery was evil,  The war was actually a needless spilling of blood, and the genocide of millions of black people ensued thereafter. All because Abe couldn't wait 25 years for a reasonable phase out. For what it's worth, it kinds was about states rights to vote for president. Basically, the entire south voted against Lincoln and still lost. Lincoln wasn't really for liberating the slaves, but the point was that it became clear that the north held all the political power. There was also a bit of a kneejerk in that it was largely assumed that the slaves would be freed.  Fun fact though, american slavery was unsustainable to an extreme degree, to the point that most plantation owners, despite looking like they were wealthy with their fine suits and huge plots of land, were actually in crippling debt. Keeping a slave fed and furnished to be able to work the fields is really expensive, and the biggest plantations had essentially small armies worth of slaves. They kept their slaves fed and adequetly equipped by taking on huge loans. By the time interest was paid on their loans, the only way they had to "improve" the plantation was to get more land (it was cheap) and buy more slaves (also cheap in relative terms compared to buying better equipment and gloves for the slaves they already had)

In then end both give their respected regions a better view on those who learn. In the north typically many are taught that the Union was ending slavery for its terrible practices while in actuality it was solely for an economic benefit and the reason the 14th and 15th amendments were created was to "thank" the people of color who fought and served the union while as history also shows they were not routinely enforced as many groups rose in opposition of this and often resulted in the death of many. The 13th amendment was only passed to as said before end slavery for its economic reasons. The south often teaches that the civil war was about the federal government (Union) imposing itself on the south while not being entirely wrong the main reason was for the south to continue slavery practices for its economic benefit. Part of the reason the civil war officially started was the south firing on the Union forts that refused to hand over control in the southern regions as they were easy strongholds to defend for the Union until reinforcements arrived. I have read from this comment section that a lot of people are not aware of history and like to take what they read/hear at face value without any sort of knowledge except ‚Äúmy 8th grade teacher said it was all about slavery‚Äù. People forget that the North, South, and Midwest were pretty much the 3 regions in the United States at the time leading up to the war. The North had become very industrialized and was not suitable for large scale farming because of the rocky soil it contained. The Midwest had some decent farming and was able to produce a lot of grain. The South is an interesting story, however. It had amazing farmland making it highly profitable for farming, and in turn slavery when the invention of the cotton gin happened. Cotton was the south‚Äôs export, and it made millions each year exporting to Europe. The majority of cotton grown in the south came from plantations. Plantations, usually, were very large and had many different slaves and workers doing different things, almost making the place self-sustainable. This is another one of the reasons that the south didn‚Äôt majorly industrialize. The north had to industrialize to make money, unlike the south that could rely on unpaid labor and exports. The government during all of this needed to make money. This led to the tariff of abominations as it was called by the south. It significantly raised taxes on imports which meant that Europe was buying less cotton from the south, hurting its economy, and also requiring the south to purchase its manufactured goods from the north, which were more expensive than the foreign ones that they had been buying. This is when the calls for secession were first majorly heard in the south. There was a compromise 5 years later or so, but the south was still slightly upset. The Midwest during all of this was still supplying the north with a majority of its food imports. This caused ties between the north and Midwest to tighten and also allowed for more railways to be built between them, which significantly helped the north during the later war.  So you see, it is not as simple as the war was entirely about slavery, and while a good portion of it was because the south felt that it was protected by the constitution, there are other reasons. I also would like to point out that the invention of the tractor would have rendered slave labor almost worthless

I remember reading about how Lincoln absolutely hated slavery, but did everything in his power to *respect* the rights of the States that had slavery institutions, protecting their "States Rights" as best he could instead of just bringing the hammer down on the whole thing the way a tyrant would.  He wanted to end slavery, but couldn't come up with a way to do it that was, at the time, the wisest choice to make.  It was way more complicated than "just free everyone lol".  The logistics of sending them to Liberia, keeping them as "separate but equal", and complete equality were all weighed and were damnable extremes given the climate at the time, unfortunately, as he knew how important Slavery was to the South and the kind of violence and, ironically, rebellion that would bring.  But because he had a hard stance against allowing the GROWTH of the institution of slavery, the South got all miffed.  And BECAUSE they decided to secede because of their "States Rights" (which, again, were being respected as sovereign because Lincoln believed the Constitution was something to be respected), the North had the *perfect* angle to pass the EP.
