Here‚Äôs how bad the economics of slavery made the confederacy:  The infrastructure of the Southern US was so focused on cash crops like cotton and tobacco that there was exactly one factory capable of producing cannons. There wasn't enough arable land to maintain cotton production for tax revenue and grow enough food to support an army. Even with the government building railroads, laying telegraph lines, and confiscating food from private farms for the war effort, the Confederate army was often malnourished and always short on manufactured goods like uniforms and guns. The problems of supply facing the Confederate army were so acute that some historians have suggested that the Battle of Gettysburg was precipitated by a Confederate brigade's attempt to raid a shoe warehouse.   Ironically, the Confederacy went into the war thinking that this trope (crippling overspecialization)would help them. They believed that they had such a stranglehold on world cotton production that Britain and France would have to intervene on their side in order to keep their textile mills running, and that Northern industry's dependence on Southern cotton would bankrupt their economy and lead them to sue for peace. Pro-secession Southern demagogues in the run-up to the Civil War referred to it as "King Cotton".   Unfortunately for them, they found that the Union and their potential European allies were not as cripplingly overspecialized as they had hoped, as the Indian and Egyptian cotton industries boomed once the US Navy started blockading and capturing Southern ports and cutting off their primary source of income. Furthermore, the UK had been stockpiling cotton reserves over the last few years, sensing the growing instability in the US, a move that was assisted by the bumper crops that the South had been producing in the late 1850s. Also, while British industry ran on Southern cotton, the nation also depended on the North for a quarter of its food supply, so intervention in support of the Confederacy would mean long bread lines in the event of a drawn-out war. Thus the famous final statement that King Corn was stronger than King Cotton. And for good measure, Britain and France had both recently ended slavery in their home countries and therefore had very little political will to be seen supporting a country whose main issue was continuing slavery.

Funny thing is though, the Confederacy was very specifically AGAINST state's rights. Which just makes the idiots defending them today with that "states rights" argument even more stupid.        It's right there, in their declaration of secession, and in their confederate constitution. Whereas the USA was for states' rights, and they were willing to die for that ideological philosophy and cause. That's a good thing. They were willing to put their lives on the line to defend that fundamental ideology of freedom and liberty and justice that the USA's founding fathers had established in the original constitution.          But yeah the confederacy was very much against states' rights and they enforced it in their own constitution they had. And it's right there in their declaration of secession. They had been mad at the Northern states because the Northern states refused to capture escaped slaves and return them to the southern states. And they were mad that the northern states were blocking the shipping routes for slaves, because slaves would be shipped to the shores of the Northern states first and then be transported over land to the southern states, but the Northern states were not allowing slaves to be shipped through their northern ports.       So the southern states tried to get the federal government to overrule the Northern states and force them to do it, i.e. specifically overrule the states' rights of all the northern states. But the federal government refused to overrule them, they refused too just like the individual northern states had refused to be a part of the slave trade. So the Southern states had an enormous temper tantrum and tried to secede, and declared war by committing acts of war against the northern states, against the union as a whole.          Not to mention their confederate constitution expressly forbade individual states from making slavery illegal, meaning they'd be overruling the States rights of their *own* states too.         They were always against state's rights. They wanted to be able to overrule the states rights of the Northern States, and when they couldn't they started a whole war over it.

Posting at the top level because some cowards have replies disabled:  ‚Äã> "The Civil War wasnt about race and Lincoln himself said that if he could keep the Union together without aboloshing slavery he would." This is a commonly argued misleading half-truth. Lincoln's concern was preserving the union, which was his concern because the south had seceded, which they had done over the matter of slavery.  > "The Civil War was primarily instigated by a technologically inferior South having a good portion of their man-power (Slaves), be stripped away by a technologically superior, industrialized North" You don't get to pretend Lincoln was threatening to abolish slavery before the war while also arguing that the war wasn't about slavery because Lincoln said so. That's just straight up doublethink. No, what the south was mad about was the north's opposition to returning escaped slaves against their will to the south, which the south had tried to force via the fugitive slave act, and the fact that new states being added to the union weren't all slave states. The south seceded because slavery was in decline and they didn't like that.  > "This also isnt touching on the fact that the North wasnt this paragon of hope like modern Twitter uses like to think." BuT tHe NoRtH wAsNt PeRfEcT Literally irrelevant, the topic here is that slavery is bad and that the south seceded because of slavery, which the war was ultimately fought over. Problems with the north do not absolve the practice of slavery, it just means that two things were bad with slavery being the worse between them, lol.  > "You cannot, in good faith, with a baseline understanding of US History, say that the Civil War was only about a State's right to continue practicing slavery" You're right, but not for the reason you think. Because while the quip is funny, the south was NOT in favor of a states' rights to respect the practice of slavery. The south was actually very much against states' rights. Specifically, again, the fugitive slave laws they wanted to pass before seceding to force northern states that didn't recognize slavery to round up and return escaped slaves from the south, and their confederate constitution explicitly forbidding member states from ever abolishing slavery within their borders. They did not like states' rights, because states' rights meant allowing states choosing to reject slavery, which was the foundational tenet of the confederacy.  > Also, no one said it was _only_ about slavery, you added that. Again, for the north, it was about preserving the union over anything else. But for the south, the #1 reason above all else was the preservation _and expansion_ of slavery. A distant, _DISTANT_ second might have been taxes (on slaves), and "states' rights" wouldn't even register.  > "Also, the Dixie Flag was barely used and is a legitimate symbol of Southern American culture, whether you like it or not." If you're going to "um actually", at least get it right. The X flag is the Virginia battle flag, which was also used as a naval ensign. The original dixie flag was the 3-bar flag with a circle of stars in the blue canton, quickly replaced by the white banner with the battle flag in the corner, later with a red stripe. Those flags were very unpopular at the time, and if the confederacy hadn't fallen, the flag would have undoubtedly been updated to the naval flag/Tennessee army flag people wave today. The whole charade over "it's not the confederate flag, it's hEriTaGe" is so overplayed, it's just boring at this point. It's the argument of a tedious pedant who is wrong about the facts. The flag originated with the confederacy and was used extensively by the confederacy, it represents the confederacy and their part in the war for slavery, and as such it represents slavery. That's the "heritage" it was created for and still represents. It is, no matter how you try to weasel your way out of it, *_A_* confederate flag, and it represents the ideals of the confederacy, which was slavery.  If you want a symbol to represent the south, find a new symbol that wasn't created by or primarily used by the confederacy. Germans aren't flying swastika flags all over the place trying to argue it's "about heritage" and has nothing to do with Nazis, and you shouldn't either.

Welp, I'm not a southern apologist or anything, but to anyone genuinely curious about the claim: the South was facing tariffs and taxation rates they really didn't like, but couldn't vote to change because the North strongly outnumbered them politically. This started a debate about whether or not a state was an independent country in a union, essentially, which they could choose to leave if it became unprofitable for them, or were more like a province in a country, that couldn't just ditch if they didn't like the federal laws. That's what people refer to when they say, in that sense, it was a war over "the United States are" and "the United States is". Are we a collective, like the EU, or a country with regions, like France?  That's not at all to say slavery wasn't involved. Looking at contemporary rhetoric, a lot of the reasons the South rebelled was because they were afraid the North was going to take away slavery, which was a crutch to their economy. And it was a more brutal kind of slavery than has been practiced for most of history as well, few other nations were as cruel and careless about their slaves as the South. South Carolina's Declaration of Secession: "...all the States north of that line have united in the election of a man to the high office of President of the United States, whose opinions and purposes are hostile to SLAVERY. He is to be entrusted with the administration of the common Government, because he has declared that that "Government cannot endure permanently half slave, half free," and that the public mind must rest in the belief that slavery is in the course of ultimate extinction... The SLAVEHOLDING States will no longer have the power of self-government, or self-protection, and the Federal Government will have become their enemy."  Mississippi's Declaration of Secession: "...position is thoroughly identified with the institution of SLAVERY- the greatest material interest of the world. Its labor supplies the product which constitutes by far the largest and most important portions of commerce of the earth."  Texas's Declaration of Secession: "We hold as undeniable truths that the governments of the various States, and of the confederacy itself, were established exclusively by the white race, for themselves and their posterity; that the African race had no agency in their establishment; that they were rightfully held and regarded as an inferior and dependent race, and in that condition only could their existence in this country be rendered beneficial or tolerable."  "... that the SERVITUDE of the African race, as existing in these States, is mutually beneficial to both bond and free, and is abundantly authorized and justified by the experience of mankind, and the revealed will of the Almighty Creator."  Confederacy's VP Alexander Stephens: "The new Constitution has put at rest forever all the agitating questions relating to our peculiar institutions--African SLAVERY as it exists among us--the proper status of the negro in our form of civilization. This was the immediate cause of the late rupture and present revolution [...] The general opinion of the men of that day [Revolutionary Period] was, that, somehow or other, in the order of Providence, the institution [slavery] would be evanescent and pass away [...] Our new Government is founded upon exactly the opposite ideas; its foundations are laid, its cornerstone rests, upon the great truth that the negro is not equal to the white man; that SLAVERY, subordination to the superior race, is his natural and normal condition."  The Confederacy itself banned its members from one thing.   "While the U.S. Constitution has a clause that states "No bill of attainder or ex post facto law shall be passed," the Confederate Constitution also added a phrase that explicitly protected slavery: Article I Section 9(4) No bill of attainder, ex post facto law, or law denying or impairing the right of PROPERTY IN NEGRO SLAVES shall be passed."  In fact, the Confederate states LOST several rights they previously held in the Union.   -States lost the right to determine if foreigners can vote in their states: Article I Section 2(1) as mentioned above. -States also lost the ability to restrict the rights of traveling and sojourning slave owners: Article IV Section 2(1) as mentioned above. (Many Southerners were already of the opinion that the U.S. Constitution already protected the rights of sojourning and traveling slave owners and that the Confederate Constitution merely made it explicit.) -The Confederate Congress could determine taxes between states. Article I Section 9(6) No tax or duty shall be laid on articles exported from any State, except by a vote of two-thirds of both Houses.   In fact, the Confederate government heavily utilized the Supremacy Clause, especially when the war was ongoing.   So secession was definitely not about slavery and about state's rights, correct? By banning the states from abolishing slavery and taking away their rights.

As someone who was raised in the south most people argued for confederate representation as a way of remembering history. Most southern folk don‚Äôt actually defend slavery and most people who waved a confederate flag (at least from what I knew) waved it to honor a dead ancestor. There are racist groups that very much agree with confederacy and argue this point, but most people don‚Äôt think this is the case. We defended the statues as a way of remembrance of what these people were like, who they chose to be, what they chose to do, what they chose to believe.   The greatest evil is the one people forget, for if we do not have the humility to recognize our errors we will never improve and grow past what we once were. There is a difference in honoring those who died in what was truly a tragic battle (brother turned against brother, father against son, families were torn apart and an unprecedented number of people for the time died on the battlefield, all for a cause that was selfishly motivated) and honoring their beliefs.   Now for some historical context that is usually left out, the north was almost fully industrialized and didn‚Äôt have any need for slaves to have a stable economy. The south however was highly agricultural, and lacked the resources to industrialize as the north had. This is where the argument comes from where people claim that the southern economy was dependent upon slavery. This however isn‚Äôt completely true. It was the wealthy who mainly owned slaves and they just so happened to also control the economy, so the common folk were basically being led by people who had everything to gain from the system as it was. This isn‚Äôt to say common folk didn‚Äôt own slaves period. They did, and there are plenty of accounts of that being the case. Additionally there were even black slave owners who argued for slavery, so don‚Äôt think this was just white people, no, it was everyone and anyone who could get in on it and had something to gain.  The southern people already had natural disdain for the north since there was a disparity in wealth for most people. The north tended to receive more trade even before the industrial age, not because they had more to trade, but simply because of location, they were closer to popular trade routes while also being on the Canadian border (French at the time, I think) . The only reason the south surpassed the north in wealth was thanks to slavery, but this all changed when the industrial age came. The north having more trade allowed to industrialize really easily and really quickly, and the south quickly lost its pull on the economy. This too fueled the war. Overall, years of arguing and bickering, growing differences and disparities all led to the civil war happening. So as to why individual people fought in the war, well, that‚Äôs more complicated, since slavery wasn‚Äôt the only motivation. Slavery however was definitely the biggest cause, and it was because without slavery the south would simply not be able to compete with the north economically. When the war ended hate continued to fill the south, the economy collapsed alongside many having died. The north took little effort to assist the south during this time, for the most part they actually neglected the south. This allowed the southern people to try and carry on their traditions. It is even debatable to say that the KKK was a symptom of the north taking zero action to look after the newly freed slaves. The south had to give reparations to freed slaves in the form of land and a mule. The north didn‚Äôt make sure the land was farmable so when these reparations were handed out, most of the slaves got terrible land and wound up selling both the mule and the land. Most went back to serving their previous masters, and the newly united country did absolutely nothing about this. Racism is an issue created and perpetuated by all of society, not just one part of it, and yes the issue is more complicated, but in all the wrong ways, in all the depressing ways.

State's Right to Secede.  Look up the Corwin Amendment. An Amendment that would have fully and constitutionally protected Slavery. It not only passed in the House, it had the votes to pass in the Senate and Abraham Lincoln even approved of it. However, the Southern States seceded despite this. It is often argued that the Confederate states seceded specifically AND ONLY because of Slavery despite the fact that the nation was on the cusp of making slavery as protected as an act as free speech and gun ownership. It's an accusation that simply does not hold water by itself.  Even if you want to argue that the Confederacy's secession was entirely for the purpose of slavery, you would have to ignore the fact that the Union did not fight to remove slavery. Slavery was still legal in the Union within border states up until after the war's end. Slaves were still owned in non-slave states such as New Jersey. Most egregious of all, the Emancipation proclamation didn't free a single slave within the Union or Union controlled Confederate territory. In fact Emancipation proclamation specifically laid out counties of retaken southern territory where slaves were still expected to remain in servitude.  It was always a war of secession. If you don't believe that simply look into Lincoln's illegally incarceration of the Maryland Legislature when it decided to vote on Seceding early into the war. Not to Join the Confederacy mind you, but to simply remove itself from the war entirely as a neutral state. This was done almost entirely due to Maryland citizens protesting the ongoing drafts that had not been approved by congress.  The Civil War was the result of a long standing debate between the ideals of Jefferson's Democratic Republicans and Hamilton's Federalists. A debate that still lives on today because it is a debate regarding the powers of the states (the people) vs the power of the federal government (the state). Simplifying the conflict to a matter of slavery is not only disingenuous, it ignores one of the most important debates regarding the founding of the Republic.

Preface; this is not a pro-confederacy objection. This IS however a rather deliberate thrashing of the overly reductive argument "states rights to do what" as it places the north in a moral high-ground it does not collectively earn and understates just how thoroughly addicted to the economic degeneration of slavery the south truly was. They weren't just morally reprehensible for the ownership of slaves, they were addicted to the practice beyond any and all ability to be reasoned with and that's why it came to violence.  The south was irreconcilable and their rebellion was predicated on the basis that nothing the north could offer them would keep the union together. The south had lost all faith in their ability to protect their right to own slaves in 1860, not 1861. The civil war was a war for state's rights to govern independently of a federated system because they had fought and lost a legislative process to equitably represent their interests disproportionately to their actual democratic representation (already bloating their congressional representation with the horrific 3/5 compromise). It is disingenuous to reductively say "the civil war was fought over slavery" because the matter of slavery became unconditional before any shots were fired on Fort Sumpter; nothing the north could offer in the form of promises or protections would undo the damage of electing an abolitionist like Lincoln. The south announced their separation from the union without bloodshed, and the north began amassing its combined forces to challenge that declaration.  The south seceded, the north postured to retake the southern states by force of arms, and this culmination of military force was what compelled the confederacy to pre-emptively attack Fort Sumpter in the defense of their own proclaimed sovereignty. If the war had been fought over slavery, the north would have passed a law of abolition, the south would have violated the law by refusing to enforce it as morally degenerate addicts will do, and the north would have declared martial law and deployed forces to compel enforcement of said emancipation.

As the more agricultural based the regions in America at the time were the more likely you may encounter a plantation with slave labor as northern states that were more developed or western states that are either frontier states or territories are not viable to be farmed as most of it is untaimed wilderness and needed to be cultivated for farming or grazing.  For perspective back when fuel still utilized lead to achieve higher octane compression rates we were operating cars that on paper could outmatch the cars post leaded fuel ban, only years later after tweaking the fuel chemical composition we were able to achieve similar octane levels to pre-ban effectiveness with the lead.  We also need to realize that the country was not as centralized as we are now, meaning that if New York factories didn't really want to play ball with southern states they could reallocate the goods to individuals to the north west (modern day mid west). Not to say the south did not have any means of producing their own equipment as they were able to outfit their armies but they would be very slow in comparison to the north and the cities they had. So when the eventual separation of the Confederacy occurred and the kick off of the war we could see that maybe really early on that the members of the Confederate armies were either the preexisting states militias that held loyalties to the states they were born in or serve for and the stanch believers that felt slavery needed to stay. Disclaimer: I‚Äôm not supporting the confederacy, but I am going to be intellectually honest so that the actual argument in its original form can be heard.  Originally, any rights not designated by the constitution to the federal government are up to the states to decide. The reason this was such a big deal was that political parties in certain states had different amounts of votes depending on the population in the house. States with slaves got more house seats with the 3/5ths compromise, this giving them more political power vs the north, who was actively trying to prevent states from being slave states for this reason. It was less of a moral dilemma than a political agenda (though we can all agree that the results make us better off today). With the North trying to prevent the South gaining more power with slaves using the federal government (they had the majority of seats in the Senate), this set what was viewed as a dangerous precedent. ‚ÄúIf the government doesn‚Äôt like it, they can just pass a federal law that supersedes any state law despite what the state or is he Constitution says.‚Äù  This is what people mean when they say ‚Äúit was about states rights‚Äù. The government reached over the constitution when it probably should have been a state decision at the time (ironically, the practice had been dying out until the invention of cotton gin, which was made in the hope of reducing slavery, which in turn helped ramp slavery up again).

First, in the debates referred to on the adjustment of the State debts; secondly, on the purchase of Louisiana and its admission into the Union; thirdly, during the war of 1813; and fourthly, on the annexation of Texas, when, we believe, one chamber of her legislature actually passed a vote of secession. No State would ever suffer itself to be used as the instrument of coercing another.‚Äô His far-seeing description in the Federalist is but too applicable to the events of the present day; and remarkable it is that he, the master spirit of the Unionists, should have denounced as ‚Äòmadness‚Äô that coercion which is adopted by his followers at the present day. ‚Ä®¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†But there was a consideration of still higher import. The Constitution was a voluntary act, framed on the principles of free, mutual assent, and common belief in its advantages. To introduce force as a means of maintaining it, would be repugnant to these principles. It would be a commencement on the voluntary system, to be continued under compulsion. Force is an attribute of monarchy; the throne represents and wields the strength of the nation. Each part is subservient to the whole, and none can revolt without foreknowledge of this force to encounter and overthrow. But the basis of a Federal Republic is the reverse of all this. It stands upon consent, which is the abnegation of force. In place of submission of part to the whole, the parties are co-equal. Compulsion is not only inapplicable, but opposed to the principle of the system. And the men of that day were too logical to be unaware of this; they declined to incorporate with the structure they were rearing a principle directly antagonistic to it.‚Äù Excerpt from ‚ÄúThe American Union: It‚Äôs Effect on National Character and Policy‚Äù(1862) by James Spence, an anti-slavery Englishman  If there was a left wing secessionist movement a majority of liberals would probably support it (as they did support the Seattle ‚Äúautonomous zone‚Äù in 2020.) Instead, freed slaves were often neglected by union soldiers or faced rampant disease, including horrific outbreaks of smallpox and cholera. Many of them simply starved to death‚Ä¶ After combing through obscure records, newspapers and journals Downs believes that about a quarter of the four million freed slaves either died or suffered from illness between 1862 and 1870. He writes in the book that it can be considered ‚Äòthe largest biological crisis of the 19th century‚Äô and yet it is one that has been little investigated by contemporary historians‚Ä¶ Many northerners were little more sympathetic than their southern opponents when it came to the health of the freed slaves and anti-slavery abolitionists feared the disaster would prove their critics right.‚Äù -The Guardian, June 16, 2012  ‚ÄúAll things are subject to interpretation. American public high school lasts longer than the Confederacy did.
One thing I do want to add to the conversation, that many do seem to ignore when it comes to this whole debackle... Yes, obviously slavery was an issue. HOWEVER, this issue starts from the moment the dust settled in 1783 when we told the Brits "AAAAND STAY OUT!". The entire US, as it was at the time, was scarred by the war. Villages and cities burned, farmlands shredded, you name it. Then you have disease, and lots of cripples from the war itself. The new country had a bit of rebuilding to do as a result, and this was true for both the North *and* South. The North however had a huge advantage coming into this as they controlled three of the four busiest ports in the new USA, Boston, New York, and Baltimore. The South had Charles Town. Those leaving Europe for a new life in the New World would end up entering one of the three mentioned, and found work pretty quickly, meanwhile not very many were landing in Charles Town, and not many from the North were moving South, and seeing as food was a bit of an issue, someone had to till the fields in the South while the reconstruction was going on in the cities and towns.  Slavery basically became a necessary evil, one that was actually on the downward trend until the freaking cotton gin was invented. At which point the opposite effect of the one desired happened.  Now, I do not say this to say that the South was in the right, but, when the alternative is starvation, you don't get many options but to continue using slaves.  As for the whole issue itself come time for the war to kick off, one should remember that many viewed the US at the time as just a collective of smaller countries, each with the ability to govern itself, and set its own rules outside of that of the Constitution. This included setting tariffs on imported goods, taxes within the state, and so on. There was also a bit more... comradary? Among those that live in that state, since when you're standing shoulder to shoulder getting ready for a long march, it helped to know that the guy next to you was someone who could relate to your personal struggles. Something that many today certainly don't understand (For example the many in NYC who think you shouldn't own a rifle, compared to those that live in Oklahoma on a farm who need one to protect their livestock).  This is where the actual point of "States Rights" comes into play. Not just slavery, but the ability of each state to set its own laws, taxes, and more. And it's coming up again right now with other issues from firearms and free speech, to abortion and trans issues. Some believe that the issues should be handled at a federal level, and all states must abide, others, like myself, feel that the Federal Government is overstepping its bounds, and that states should be allowed to set their own rules. I don't mind the idea of the Feds saying "OK guys, here's some guidelines", but the idea of the Feds coming into a statehouse and saying "You can only parrot what we say", is too far.  The reason I believe in this is because the Federal Government is typically very slow to react to many issues, and isn't really capable of adjusting itself very well. What works in one state may not actually work, or even be necessary in another. New York, which of course has Manhattan (one of the most densely populated areas in the US) obviously required mask mandates to try and reduce the spread of COVID... Montana, where much of the population is spread out, didn't. Some EPA laws that work in California because of its unique geography, simply won't work as well in states like Oklahoma where it's mostly flat.  Basically, each state has its own unique requirements and challenges, and the Feds are not equipped to handle it all. The state governments are the best suited for those challenges. Those state reps live there, they breath the air, they drink the water, they eat the food, and they're much closer to the mouths of the people who live in those states. You may have a Senator in DC from Idaho for example, but he/she is a long way from it, and they'll have a hard time trying to convince a Senator from NY or PA that this bill is a good or bad idea. Meanwhile a State Rep will have a much easier time convincing the rep from the next county over if the bill he/she is proposing is a good idea or not.  So... short of the long: "States rights to govern themselves as they see fit instead of the over-reach of the Federal Government."

As a Southerner, I can say that it was bad.
Slavery absolutely was an immoral thing, and no honest and good person in modern day western countries will defend it. However, the argument "state's rights to do what" kinda misses the point. Yes, it was for slavery, but more than that it was for states to be allowed to decide themselves if slavery was to be allowed or outlawed within their borders. It eventually boiled down to an argument on not if slavery was wrong, but if it was within the rights of the federal government to force the issue one way or the other, and by a future outlawing nationwide without the consent of the current states it would mean certain areas would become underrepresented in their own choices. This same argument is made over the electoral college today. Also, the South ended up being correct in the fact that the federal government would eventually gain more power than should be allowed. Ever since the end of the civil war we no longer follow the constitutional form of government we were meant to have, instead it is an overarching federal government deciding things, and states governments occasionally dissent against it. It's also really important to note the north did not fight the war for the abolition of slavery, instead it was about keeping the union intact. many will point to the 1863 emancipation proclamation as a counter to that, but even disregarding that it was made two years into the war, it only outlawed slavery in the confederacy. even border states that had slaves would not have them be legally freed despite the fact they were in the union! (Which is not common knowledge, but thought should be brought up, especially given the description). Also, if you REALLY wanna get into it, slavery is STILL legal within the United States, but only for prisons, which also seem to hold a staggering percentage of only one race.

This is funny but it does gloss over some valid counter points. First I do want to say it absolutely was about the abolition of slaves, but not in it's entirety. And 2nd to get an idea of the culture, many and possibly even most of the abolitionists wanted to send black people to Africa. They wanted to end slavery because they hated black people and that's something many people didn't realize.  Now, on to pre-civil war politics. The abridged version, the Whigs were the party that the abolitionists voted with because they were the major party, think of libertarians voting for Republicans today. The Whigs weren't committed to abolition but they were willing to try to limit the power of slave states in the union. So for several years and several states being added to the union the Whigs and the Democrats were essentially duking it out in a power struggle but nether party really wanting to have a decisive victory because "other side bad" is a wedge issue that get each side votes. But the Whigs did want to frustrate slavery because that was a major industry for Whig states and they did want some power over them so weakening their economy helped. In response the democrats churned out racist propaganda to drum up support of slavery. Along comes Abe Lincoln and the republican party, a more extreme pro abolition party. He united the north and drew great support as the first president of the abolitionist party.  The Whigs and the Democrats hated him because he threw a wrench into their little scheme. He also pulled away supporters from the mainline Whigs, kind of like what (sorry Abe) Trump did more recently but with more tact.  That's the abridged context of the civil war. The TL;DR version, Democrats had a kinda power struggle with the Whigs but were in a comfortable spot. Abe won the election as a Republican, an abolitionist party and the Democrats were like "scvrew you republicans, we are out of here" but Abe was like "no". So in a way the Democrats states were being stepped on and screwed over for a while. So in that aspect it was about states rights and not being treated as equals or feeling like their voice is being heard. Interesting they didn't apply the same reasoning to slavery. But, regardless of the nuiance the major concern was still slavery.

Historically, the Civil War was about slavery AMONG MANY OTHER THINGS.  You have to remember, the south was entirely dependent on the agricultural economy, the north already outnumbered them, massive cultural differences between the northern "Yanks" (Anglo heritage) and the southern "Dixie" (Scots and Irish heritage).  The north basically was forcing the south into poverty and hundreds of thousands of normal men fought in the war, not just northern politicians and southern land-owners.  Ultimately the war was TRULY fought over one thing, if you joined the USA, was the membership permanent?  The north said yes and the south said no, it just so happened that due to the economic framework of the time, one of the primary catalysts for the war was slavery, among many other political, cultural and socio-economic concerns.  TL;DR: The war was far more complex than we give credit to, but slavery was ultimately ONE of the main things that the Confederacy tried to preserve, which even for the time, unless you were a Barbary Pirate or an African King, was incredibly bad optics and out-of-date.

Guy was not a hypocrite, he couldn't stand the idea of robbing people of their freedoms. He hated big governments and favored small Constitutional Republics where the elected lived among their constituents and had clear limitations on their authority.    He however, saw it his duty to care for those slaves he had inherited as he couldn't see a way for them to succeed with no education on their own,  not necessarily a correct view but i can vibe with the intent of a provider. I‚Äôm a little late to this but to all confederacy retards ( I‚Äôm not disparaging against the mentally disabled, just these idiots):  Poaceae (/po äÀàe…™sia…™, -siÀêiÀê/) or Gramineae (/…°r…ôÀàm…™nia…™/) is a large and nearly ubiquitous family of monocotyledonous flowering plants commonly known as grasses. It includes the cereal grasses, bamboos and the grasses of natural grassland and species cultivated in lawns and pasture. The latter are commonly referred to collectively as grass.  Grasses Temporal range: Albian‚ÄìPresent  PreÍûíÍûíOSDCPTJKPgN [1]  Flowering head of meadow foxtail (Alopecurus pratensis), with stamens exerted at anthesis Scientific classification Edit this classification Kingdom: Plantae Clade: Tracheophytes Clade: Angiosperms Clade: Monocots Clade: Commelinids Order: Poales Clade: Graminid clade Family: Poaceae Barnhart[2] Type genus Poa L. Subfamilies Anomochlooideae Aristidoideae Arundinoideae Bambusoideae Chloridoideae Danthonioideae Ehrhartoideae Micrairoideae Panicoideae Pharoideae Pooideae Puelioideae Synonyms[3] Gramineae Juss.  With around 780 genera and around 12,000 species,[4] the Poaceae is the fifth-largest plant family, following the Asteraceae, Orchidaceae, Fabaceae and Rubiaceae.[5]  The Poaceae are the most economically important plant family, providing staple foods from domesticated cereal crops such as maize, wheat, rice, barley, and millet as well as feed for meat-producing animals. They provide, through direct human consumption, just over one-half (51%) of all dietary energy; rice provides 20%,[6] wheat supplies 20%, maize (corn) 5.5%, and other grains 6%[citation needed]. Some members of the Poaceae are used as building materials (bamboo, thatch, and straw); others can provide a source of biofuel, primarily via the conversion of maize to ethanol.  Grasses have stems that are hollow except at the nodes and narrow alternate leaves borne in two ranks. The lower part of each leaf encloses the stem, forming a leaf-sheath. The leaf grows from the base of the blade, an adaptation allowing it to cope with frequent grazing.  Grasslands such as savannah and prairie where grasses are dominant are estimated to constitute 40.5% of the land area of the Earth, excluding Greenland and Antarctica.[7] Grasses are also an important part of the vegetation in many other habitats, including wetlands, forests and tundra.  Though they are commonly called "grasses", groups such as the seagrasses, rushes and sedges fall outside this family. The rushes and sedges are related to the Poaceae, being members of the order Poales, but the seagrasses are members of order Alismatales. However, all of them belong to the monocot group of plants. I see a lot of people in the comments giving the old ‚ÄúLincoln didn‚Äôt actually care about slavery, he just wanted to preserve the Union‚Äù argument. Chapter six of *Lies My Teacher Told Me* by James W. Loewen explains why that interpretation is totally wrong.  To summarize:  The Republican Party chose Lincoln over another presidential candidate for the 1860 election precisely because Lincoln was harder on slavery.  The quote where Lincoln claims that he would preserve the Union without freeing the slaves is almost always presented out of context. In context, Lincoln was writing a letter to the New York Tribune during a time when New York City was one of the largest white supremacist cities in the north. If he wanted to drum up Union support for the war, he had to downplay the importance of ending slavery. Even so, in the same letter, he does state that ending slavery is his personal wish.  He also desegregated White House staff and opened the White House to Black callers, such as Frederick Douglas.  The Emancipation Proclamation was actually politically risky and cost Lincoln‚Äôs party control of congress the following November, which contradicts the idea that Lincoln only gave the speech as a shrewd political move and not because he passionately cared about ending slavery, which he did.  Was Lincoln ideologically perfect? No. But anyone who tells you that Lincoln was indifferent to slavery is either wrong or actively lying.

Def not a confederate supporter, but there was certainly cultural differences between the north and the south. You have to remember that in the north a lot of the descendants came from Puritans from the 1600s as well as many immigrants from multiple European nations. Where is the south was primarily Scottish and English of Anglican dissent. Slavery 100% was a part of it, there is no argument about that, but you also have to remember that there was several border states who cited with the union that were also slave states such as Delaware and Maryland, even though they did have individuals within that state that were split on the issue and actually did fight for the confederacy. There was also taxation on Southern goods as well and they were cultural differences all the way back to the American revolution where many southerners actually were pro loyalist more so than in the north, and during the war of 1812, there was far more supporters in the south, then there was the New England to fight the British. There was also the thought of manifest destiny were mini Northerners were afraid at the south would expand slavery into new territory taken from Mexico. Also, you have to remember that by 1860, the slavery was still an issue, only 12% of southerners owned slaves, and even a smaller percentage out of that owned massive plantations. Within the world, slavery was dying off, even Brazil got rid of their slaves in 1883, which was 18 years before slavery within the United States, ended. In regards to the union and the emancipation proclamation, it only freed the slaves within the rebel held states, states who had sided with union who had slaves had kept their slaves until the 13th amendment after the war in 1865.

Slight clarification: the Confederacy wasn't worried about Lincoln abolishing slavery, but that he would not enable the expanding of slavery to new states in the Union. They were seceding because they saw the writing on the wall that eventually, in however many years, the slave states would be outnumbered by free states, and would eventually vote to abolish it federally. Lincoln's priority even after the war started was preserving the Union, not abolishing slavery, and he only abolished it when it became clear that freeing the slaves was key to winning the war. I should point out that, while the Confederacy was built on slavery, the issue *does* deserve to be looked at from a light that's more than just "black and white". Lincoln may have hated slavery and personally wanted its abolishment, but he made it pretty damn clear with the South and during his campaign that he wasn't going to forcibly abolish the institution of slavery. In fact, Lincoln was quite hesitant to actually abolish slavery as an institution explicitly because he had neither the political clout or broader public support to do so until *during* the Civil War, and even then the Emancipation Proclamation amounted to a big gamble on Lincoln's part to drum up morale and support in the North.  Also, I'd like to point out the hilarious hypocrisy of any American telling others they can't pull away from a govt that they feel is becoming too tyrannical on their local rights, especially when our very founding is based on lies or exaggerations that the Founding Fathers told to dirt-poor farmers, delinquents, and drunkards who had no real access to the information that was being passed around beyond the confines of monopolistic newspapers affiliated with them, especially in Boston where Benjamin Franklin held monopoly on news and media. The Stamp Act only affected less than a quarter of the population of the Colonies. Taxation without representation is incredibly misunderstood, especially considering that the governor generals of the Colonies *was* their representation to put legislation to Parliament. King George III didn't have any real de-facto power, as by that point the UK had, for nearly a century, been a Constitutional Monarchy. And taxation in the UK was actually worse than in the Colonies by a substantial margin, and not only that, but American colonists were paid more than British citizens were. Let's not forget that, immediately after the Revolution, Congress basically tried to tax Americans who fought in the Revolution to pay for itself, only to end up getting near another rebellion before it was put down. Maybe, and I'm just saying maybe, not EVERYONE who thinks the American Civil War was a bit of a gray area is just a brain-dead racist? Don't get me wrong, it's a wonderful strawman that feels great to beat the tar out of because slavery is awful and the serf-esque system cropping up in a few areas of the south was barely any better (you're free so I'll pay you, now grow all my money for this relative pittance), but all you did here was make yourself the butt-end of an old Simpson's joke (Apu's citizenship test, for any wondering).  I'm not a history buff of any sort, let alone regarding the Civil War, but some of what I'm aware of is as follows: Slavery was undeniably a part of the Civil War, but so were the massive trade tariffs which disproportionately affected the south, since trading their slave-produced goods with Europe was how they made the majority of their money. Being able to trade without paying the massive taxes they would have with the Union was so appealing to the Confederacy that they were willing to make an agreement with the British to reopen trade and abolish slavery (feasibly to just replace it with the aforementioned already-appearing serf system where a non-insignificant number of the now-freed slaves would have been convinced to accept pittance pay because "wHaT oThEr JoBs CoUlD yOu EvEn Do?"). Heck, slavery was SO blatantly the ONLY cause of the war that the Emancipation Proclamation, which specifically only declared slaves in territory controlled by the Confederacy free, caused a large number of the Union's soldiers to desert (as in a bunch of the "good-guys" who "weren't the ones keeping slavery going" quit fighting because their leader said the people they were fighting couldn't own slaves anymore). The desertion was so bad Lincoln revved up conscription (the draft), which in turn led to rioting, which at least in New York was put down by some of the remaining Union soldiers with a lot of civilian deaths caused by both rioters and soldiers. What are the other concerns exactly? Slavery is bad, but I wanna know what other concerns these people have. If it's just slavery than I'll apologize for prying, but now I'm curious.
1) The narrative that the entire war was fought purely over freeing/keeping slaves isn't true. It was only one factor among more, and it was mainly a motivator during the beginning and ending for PR. Lincoln himself is quoted, and you can google this, "If I could save the union without freeing any slaves I would do it; and if I could save it by freeing all the slaves I would do it; and if I could save it by freeing some and leaving others alone I would also do that." He also declared that Whites and Blacks were not equal and did not want them to become equal in another quote I'd post but he used the forbidden n-word. Jefferson Davis, President of the CSA, stated that he'd rather free the slaves than continue the Union, which should show that this was more than just them but about the relationship with the US government and local states. Thomas "Stonewall" Jackson taught his slaves to read (why would he if he was fighting to keep them enslaved?), General Lee freed his own, and the CSA not only let Blacks join their ranks but paid them the same as Whites, while the North not only segregated their units but paid Blacks half as much. Northern States like New Jersey were known as the Slave State, the famous Wall Street used to be a major hub for selling slaves that rivaled New Orleans. The Northern States even proposed an amendment that would allow slavery to continue if the South didn't secede. Even Irish people used as Indentured Servants (slavery under contract) if the North was opposed to it. So as we can see, this wasn't simply cut and dry about owning slaves.   2) Economic reasons, like almost all wars are fought. The Union did not like the states going around their taxes and selling stuff directly to other countries, while the South felt that the taxes were too harsh and was forcing them to. Which leads to my next point.   3) The North had most of the cities while the South was very agrarian, this meant that the Northern states had more voting power than the South. If you're being outvoted and can't change the tax, what else are you going to do? Not to mention they were importing more people by the thousands who'd vote for whoever they were told and promised a better life. Gangs of NY shows this very well  4) As for slavery itself, despite what you hear it wasn't as profitable as people made it to seem. The Industrial Revolution had already spread to America, which meant that less labor was needed for agrarian style jobs, while a rapid buildup of the Northern Cities was happening that could then outproduce and manufacture the South. Slaves did not build this country, it was already built and being built further by the Whites who were the supermajority at over 98% demographic wise. All those cities were build by working class Whites, all those towns and neighborhoods the same. Blacks picked crops like cotton, oranges, and tobacco which were often sold overseas. Most of the FF believed slavery was on its way out and would do so over time.   5) Fear of a Haitian style slave revolt. If you know your French history, you know what happened to them in Haiti where Whites were slaughtered horrifically, followed by the mixed race offspring. It's mentioned in both CSA propaganda and the discourse of their government. The French freed the Haitians in 1793, 11 years later the Haitians slaughtered them down to the last men, women, and children  6) Land ownership. A lot of Whites not only did not own land but were either renting it from someone else, or were living in the wilds, and the war promised the ownership of land that was actually good as opposed to living in swamps.  These are a few reasons. Yes some, mainly the upper classes, did fight for slavery because they wanted to maintain their business and wealth, nobody disputes that. But a lot of it also had to do with the North using immigration to get more votes and taxing the other states. Most of the actual people fighting in the Confederacy saw it as having enough of the North and wanting out. If the CSA won, they'd have had to abolish slavery and deport them back to Africa anyway since slaves were used for cheap labor and they'd need to keep the people employed or else risk their own revolt from within by war hardened veterans.

It works the same way now, wheras companies are looking to automation to take the place of paying workers to do menial tasks (as a machine should /technically/ not break down as much as the average worker would get paid. This depends on the machine, ofcourse but that is the general view) and thus increase their output and profit. Generally speaking, human capital is meaning less and less as technology advances. I‚Äôm personally tired of this reductive view of slavery and the confederacy. For starters I have lived in the North for all my life and do partially resent the confederacy because it although the events of the civil war happened 20 years before my ancestors even came to the states.   The thing I hate about this take is that it just reduces the view points of people as evil racist and good unifier. The confederacy and the battle of slavery was deeply complex, so much so even the founders knew it would be a source of deep divide for the nation.   The view points of slavery at the time were deeply informed by theocracy and historical precedent. Historically slaves had been in every nation through the entirety of history. There were some states that freed slaves but they were always had no need of the institution anyways and was typically short lived. The First Nation to remove slavery was Demark in the the 1790s. More importantly England banned slavery in the 1833 but none of these nations had major slave populations in their actual borders. They did not live, work, and speak to slaves so it was an easy move to make the change to go from official property to slave wages and sovereign control. Negro slaves were especially by no means legal equals to the whites that‚Äôs used to own them. So in most of the the confederacy founders lifetime slavery went from the unquestioned law of the land and a ‚Äúmoral good‚Äù to an evil abomination.   How can slavery ever had been considered a moral good at any time? Well here we enter the religious context of the time. The Bible makes very clear references to slavery and how to conduct slavery morally as both slave owner and slave. This meant that the literal word of God promoted the institution of slavery and as most in the south were extremely devout Christians the connection with chattel slavery was easy and apparent. Further the religious perspective at the time re-enforced the idea that that slavery was a calling for the Christian Slave owners and people. At the time a question puzzled religious leaders at the time when the new world was discovered, why had these people not heard the word of God? Why do they not worship Jesus and the lord as we do? This question led to the conclusion that it must be that Gods plan and duty for them was to teach them the word of God. They believed God had blessed them with there far superior technology to take these people as slaves and educated them through labor to improve all their lives.   This was incredibly misguided at best but makes sense when you consider their understanding of the world as the total supremacy of God. Most members of confederacy really did believe that slavery was a sort of holy mission. ‚ÄúThrough labor, piety, and discipline African slaves would be made proper men of God‚Äù could be said to be the slogan of the confederacy. Horribly ridiculous to all of us but we do have a world view that starts at God. There were also of course people which really help uphold this world view.   Another major force at work in the preservation of slavery was that slavery was no longer necessary. Money and finance had finally evolved out of the dark age and things like wages became a practical thing to do. This was also the age of the machine and the need for massive labor was becoming irrelevant. Slavery was becoming unprofitable and nearly dead in every industry besides cotton until the cotton gin was invented. It after all was far easier to simple pay someone a meager wage and let them figure out their accommodations rather than responsible for the process yourself. Feeding, Clothing, and caring for slaves was very expensive and difficult. Like caring for work horses it is a Job in itself that requires a ridiculous amount of money and attention. It would be much more practical to just lose a bit of money and have them take care of it then for you to do it. Also remember that some of these people hate your guts, some do not really care so long as they are treated right, and maybe one or two actually like you. You have to spend time and money to keep order. Compared to wage where I can say ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt like me, we‚Äôll have fun starving because I‚Äôm the only one who‚Äôll pay you‚Äù. Order is ensured by the need for money.   So why did the south want to hold onto slavery despite the inefficiency? Because it was their ‚ÄúGod given right‚Äù(eww) and it was their ‚Äúholy‚Äù mission. There were the other concerns with the expansion of Unitary Powers that did ultimately become true.   So why do I see Goobus as being reductive while masquerading as wisdom? Because he does not know the context and simply says ‚Äúsouth bad‚Äù. He also doesn‚Äôt understand the reason the idea of the confederacy became so ingrained as a cultural icon in the south.   The antagonism between north and south did not start with slavery not did end. The north always viewed the south as backwood peasant morons since the founding of the republic. Their was an immense cultural divide between the two regions for decades before and especially after the war. That more than any other reason led to the civil war although slavery was the featured part of that divide. After the war the North really did devastate the south. They sacked Atlanta which left deep wounds in the hearts of southerners for decades after the war. This was also the start of the carpetbagging of the south where southern governing and industries were put in the hands of northern cronies at the expense of southerners. The many dirty deeds done during and after the war in the mind of southerners created a great resentment in the minds of southern. Yes the lost cause education codified this but it was deep and present perception of the south. This perception was distrust and hated of the northern states with some good reason. This is what led to the confederate flags and hero‚Äôs becoming a part of their ‚Äúheritage‚Äù. Confederate imagery was used as the lighting rod to say ‚Äúfuck the carpetbagging north this terror will be payed for‚Äù which led to the  ‚ÄúSouth will rise again‚Äù mentality. Not to establish slavery but rather to give the north the just deserts they deserved and the love for their states.   As a northerner I can‚Äôt help but agree with this concept somewhat. The north was mostly unmolested during the whole war while the south was deeply devastated. The south had no hope to win the war and they knew it. They just wanted to make it such a blood bath the north would leave them alone. The north did commit needless atrocities during the war and really did not need to do so. It likely shortened the war but at high cost against the people who would be Americans after the war.   All I will say to end this is to say that slavery, the confederacy, and the rest are incredibly deep topics. They are not easily addressed by saying slavery = bad ~ slavery = confederacy ~ confederacy = bad. It‚Äôs better not to say anything if you are just going to reduce  it to such a basic level. It does nothing to address the hurts of history and rather just inflamed tensions in order to give yourself and others and unearned sense of moral superiority by chastising straw men. It was a state's right to self govern economic policy, along with their own "property" rights. At the time, slaves were legally considered property, equivalent to a piece of furniture or appliance. So the federal government making it clear that slavery was soon to be abolished would be the legal equivalent of today's federal government making wooden furniture illegal, and several states seceding in protest. The idea was that it was government overreach to outlaw something so vital to the economy of so many states, and that if the government was allowed to do so it would have legal precedent to continue to make massive widespread changes to the economy and livelihoods of any given state with no way for the state to defend itself.  In the end they kind of ended up being right, as the federal government has vastly more control over the states than it did during the civil war.

In case anyone is wondering, the _other_ "right" the Confederacy claimed was being infringed was their right to make unlimited money.  See, the slavery model of business is a feedback loop:  the more slaves one owned, the more money you could make, to spend on even more slaves. The reason the Civil War happened when it did was because of the invention of the combine harvester, which could replace the jobs of hundreds of people with one driver and a pack of mules, and do that job with machine efficiency.  That meant anybody in the North who wanted their own super-farm just had to buy one, and overnight destroyed their dependence on the Southern plantation model.  The plantation owners just wanted to ban that technology for no better reason than it cut into their dominance of the market... but even then that dominance depended on slave labor so yes, still about slavery. Yes, the South did maintain that the decision of slavery was a state responsibility, and not Federal. Anything that is not listed in the Constitution's enumeration of powers technically belongs to the states. The Constitution does not specifically give the Federal government say over slavery. It does does however give the Federal government power over International and interstate commerce. It also gives the Federal government control over citizenship. By 1807 over half of the states in the US had either abolished or had laws phasing out slavery, and the Federal government banned the import of slaves. While the South was right in saying that slavery was a state right, it is superseded by the Federal government's ability to declare someone a citizen and thus entitled to all the rights of a citizen (which those opposed to slavery believed that slaves were already entitled to those rights as children of God).

Lincoln said himself it wasn't about slavery: "If there be those who would not save the Union, unless they could at the same time save slavery, I do not agree with them. If there be those who would not save the Union unless they could at the same time destroy slavery, I do not agree with them. My paramount object in this struggle is to save the Union, and is not either to save or to destroy slavery. If I could save the Union without freeing any slave I would do it, and if I could save it by freeing all the slaves I would do it; and if I could save it by freeing some and leaving others alone I would also do that."  Stated in a letter dated August 22, 1862 from Lincoln to Horace Greeley. From Bleeding Kansas, to the enslavement of captured Black Union Soldiers (and free Black Civilians taken captive during the Gettysburg Campaign), and the rise of hate groups like the White League and the KKK, who among other crimes, harassed and/or murdered free Blacks and any White Northerners they could find, and attempted other Uprisings like the Battle Of Liberty Place in New Orleans, (fun fact: former Confederate General James Longstreet actually commanded a Black and White militia to try and fend off the White League during the Uprising, and he was shot in the leg while fighting, he was smart enough to leave well enough alone after the war, and in my opinion,  was one of the few "good Confederates").

Doobus' explanations were more than enough, but here's a little more: Slavery was a pressing issue in American politics EVER SINCE ITS INCEPTION. The 3/5ths compromise was proof of this. Not to mention, for up to half a century before the civil war broke out, Congress had been trying to hold the country together with bandaids by keeping the balance of free and slave states equal as more states joined the union. The compromise of 1850 allowed California to tip the scales in congress in favor of free states in exchange for the enactment of the fugitive slave act. Not to mention, there was WIDESPREAD VIOLENCE in Kansas because the government decided to let the status of Kansas as a free or slave state be determined by a vote. The event was called BLEEDING KANSAS. Remember Texas? You know how there was a whole war fought between the US and Mexico because Texas joined the US? The reason that Texas joined the US over Mexico is because Mexico had outlawed slavery in 1829.  One thing I will support that some Pro-southerners will say is that a vast majority of confederate soldiers were probably not fighting because they wanted to keep their slaves. The majority of slaves were owned by large plantation owners, with roughly 75% of southerners not even owning a single slave. So if your grandad fought for the confederacy, that didn't necessarily make him an evil person. The confederacy was controlled by people who wanted to protect their financial interests, ie the massive plantation slave owners. It's THEIR interests that represent the interests of the Confederacy of the whole, and their interest was keeping their slaves. It's as simple as that. On the Library of Congress website, I found this one book from a Southern historian written after Reconstruction. The book was intended to chronicle the aggressions of the North for future historians. I was morbidly curious to see what it had to say, so I skimmed through about 100 Pages of complaining about Northerners until I saw a line where the author mentioned that black men couldn't be trusted due to the "negro's savage nature".  As a black guy from the future that guy was writing for, I find it hard to care about "northern aggression" when the writer literally thinks my entire race consists of Savages. Throughout the book, he complains about Lincoln and Northerners not actually caring about black people, but when the author calls me a savage, and Lincoln signs the Emancipation Proclamation, choosing a side of history is easy lol.  Edit: incase anyone was curious, I found the book in my history: Facts and Falsehoods concerning the war on the South, George Edmonds. Turns out, he wrote it in 1904!  "Rapes of young matrons and maidens and little girl children were not known in the south until after the savage, but slumbering instincts of the negro nature had been awakened"  A line like that being written for "historians" is what made it so insane to me, that even decades after the war, in the 20th century, that's the image some southerners thought to cling onto.

As someone who's in a ton of college history courses, the green toxic slime man is right in saying that there are some situations that aren't grey. The South started the war because of slavery, and every defense you can try to give them is inherently tied to slavery. The only possible grey element to the Civil War was that the North developed way faster than the South due to trade routes and better communication with the growing West. However, this caused the South to believe their only way of developing themselves on par with the North, was through slavery. This thus led to there being a big cultural divide between the North and the South. That said, the cultural and economic divide between both areas was BASED upon slavery. Even if the North never helped develop the South, which they did do, just to a lesser extent, it is never right to build something culturally and economically off the predudice and force servitude of people. Most historians want there to be grey elements to every conflict, since it puts into perspective how multiple factors helped develop our modern day. It helps make it easier for humans to learn from our mistakes, while also letting us know that both good and evil ideas are inherently apart of humanity. That said, you should never forgo the truth of a matter to pertain to your perspective. That's why revisionist history is a terrible thing, and why we should accept that some things can be black and white. I didn't expect to go on a tangent at this funny vid, but I felt it necessary to all those people trying to find the grey in a black and white conflict. Now, lets laugh at funny man okay?

An interesting take that I've heard is that there is a disparity between the soldiers of the confederacy and its leadership. The leaders were most definitely racists who seceded for the sake of the continuation of slavery, but the Confederate soldiers were answering the call to arms of their states in a day and age where state nationalism surpassed federal nationalism significantly.   Since most confederate descendants are far and away descended from the soldiery, rather than their leaders, it would make sense that those soldiers would tell their kids that they were fighting for their state, rather than slavery. Remember that it was a significant minority of southerners who actually had slaves. When people bring up that there's more to the civil war happening than a state's rights and slavery, there was: state economics. The thing is though, the economics that the confederacy was concerned about keeping were fuelled by slavery. Basically, the Southern states put their eggs into one basket, that basket being agriculture done by slaves. The agriculture businesses would eventually make up most of the states' economies. This meant that abolishing slavery would require these states to, y'know, actually pay their workers. So yeah, it was about more than just slavery, but the other things it was about *were also connected to slavery.*

Like with any moment from history, boiling it's cause down to one simple word or action is both difficult and tends to be reductionist and exclude important contributing factors.  Now in no one am I saying that the succession of the south wasn't over tension caused by pro-slavery and abolitionist movements and ideals of the time.  What I'm saying is any historical monuments rare are something caused by a single definable moment, event, or phrase. And to attempting to do so is often harmful to the true deep rich meaning and context of that historical event.

I actually really appreciate you linking some primary sources in your channel description supporting your argument. If you want even MORE proof that the Confederacy was made to defend slavery, check out the Letters of Secession (also known as the Ordinance of Succession), which constituted not only a declaration of their departure from the union and nullification of the Federal Constitution, but also lists out their reasoning for doing so. You will not go more than 2 paragraphs on any of these ordinances without seeing some mention of slavery or slaveholding states.  These ordinances were public, official laws passed to justify to the world why they are separating from the union. A more authoritative source for the Southern perspective on why the Confederacy was made and why the Civil War happened you simply cannot find (indeed, many of the ordinances had direct references to the upcoming Civil War). The folks in charge understood precisely what they were doing, why they were doing it, and where their actions would lead.  In short, "State's Rights to do what?" indeed.

As a former Marxist and current centrist I‚Äôve had to consider the material incentives behind the south‚Äôs bid to keep slavery going. The southern economy was so reliant on slavery that to suddenly abolish it would likely have catastrophic consequences in an era when a bad economy meant literal starvation. In the modern era it would be like suddenly drastically increasing the prices of all goods manufactured in countries with lower working standards: it might help other countries but it would definitely hurt us. How angry can you really be at someone for doing the wrong thing when doing the right thing would be so painful and risky? Had the north and south made a compromise to gradually grant more rights to slaves then the civil war might have never happened. Yes it feels gross to make such compromises but lasting progress requires time and patience. Instant emancipation was never a realistic outcome and it didn‚Äôt really improve the lives of former slaves for a long time.  Of COURSE slavery and racism are wrong and bad and are unacceptable in today‚Äôs culture because of how long it‚Äôs been since our nation had a turning point on those issues, but if you ask me it would have been better for the turning point to have been more peaceful

this is a good video illustrating some really poor arguments, but the civil war was actually just a little gray. slavery, for as easy and rightful as it is to condemn from afar, was responsible for the south's economic stability and growth. there was a legitimate fear that the removal of slaves in one fell swoop could cause entire states to economically collapse, leading to worse living conditions for everyone involved.  there's also the fact that abraham lincoln wasn't the equality loving sweetheart he was made out to be. after freeing the slaves, no further efforts to protect or help the displaced slaves was proposed by him, and many were simply left for dead, now without masters, but also without a roof over their head, or food to eat. many slaves simply were not adjusted for life outside slavery, and either perished, or ended up exploited in much the same way, just for pennies instead of nothing.  fucked up as it is, the civil war, despite its central issue being slavery, was almost entirely an enconomic one.
